div.p: With new Additions of Mr. Chaughs and Trimtrams Roaring, and the Bauds Song. Neuer before Printed.
As it was Acted before the King, by the Prince his Highnesse Seruants.
Written by Thomas Midleton, and William Rowley. Gent.
Printed at London for I. T. and are to be sold at Christ Church Gate. 1617.

div.head: TO THE NOBLY DISposed, vertuous, and faithfull-brested Robert Grey Esquire, one of the Grooms of his Highnesse Bed-Chamber, his poore Well-willer, wisheth his best wishes. Hic es Supra.

body.p:
TIs but a Play, and a Play is but a Butt, against which many shoote many Arrowes of Enuy, 'tis the weaker Part, and how much more noble shall it be in you to defend it, yet if it be (as some Philosophers haue left behind'um) that this Megacosme, this great world, is no more then a Stage, where euery one must act his part, you shall of necessity haue many part-takers, some long, some short, some indifferent, all some, whilst indeed the Players themselues haue
the least part of it, for I know few that haue lands, (which are a part of the World) and therefore no grounded men, but how soeuer they serue for mutes, happily they must weare good cloathes for attendance, yet all haue exits and must all be stript in the Tyring-house (viz, the graue) for none must carry anything out of the stocke, you see Sir, I write as I speak, & I speak as I am, & thats excuse enough for me. I did not meane to write an Epistle of praise to you, it lookes so like a thing, (I know) you loue not Flattery, which you exceedingly hate actiuely, and vnpleasingly accept passiuely: indeed I meant to tell you your owne, that is, that this child of the Muses is yours, who euer begat it, tis laid to your charge and (for ought I know) you must father and keep it too, if it please you, I hope you shall not bee asham'd of it neither for it has beene seene (though I say it) in good companies, and many haue said it is a handsome pretty spoken infant, now be your owne iudge, at your leasure looke on it, at your pleasure laugh at it, and if you be sorry it is no better you may be glad it is no bigger.

div.head: Actus primus, Scaena prima.

sp.speaker: Russell:

lg.l: IT must be all my eare; theres all my loue,
And that pulls on the tother, had I beene left
In a sonne behind me, while I had beene here
He should haue shifted as I did before him;
Liu'd on the freeborne portion of his wit:
But a daughter, and that an onely one, oh?
We cannot be to carefull ore, to tender,
Tis such a brittle nicenes: a meere cubbord of glasses,
The least shake breakes, or crakes em; all my aime is
To cast her vpon riches: thats the thing
We richmen call perfection, for the world
Can perfect nought without it, 'tis not neatnesse
Either in handsome wit; or handsome outside
With which one gentleman (far indebt) has courted her
Which boldnes he shall rue. He thinkes me blind,
And ignorant, I haue let him play A long time,
Seem'd to beleiue his worth; which I know nothing.
He may perhaps laugh at my easie confidence
Which closely I requite vpon his fondnesse.
For this houre, snaps him; and before his Mistris
His Saint forsooth, which he inscribes my girle,
He shall be rudely taken and disgract,
The trick will proue an euerlasting Scarcrow,
To fright poore gallants from our rich-mens daughters,

sp.stage: Enter the Lady Ager, with two seruants.

lg.l: Sister? Iue such a ioy to make you a well-come of,
Better you neuer tasted.

sp.speaker: Russ.
sp.l: Colonells come, & your son Captaine Ager;

lg.l: I know your eye would be first seru'd,
Thats the soules taster still for griefe, or ioy,
Oh if a mothers deare suit may preuaile with him,
From England; he shall neuer part agen,

sp.speaker: Russ.
sp.l: No question he'le be ruld, and grant you that,

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Ile bring all my desires to that request.

lg.l: Affectionate sister, she ha's no daughter now
It followes all the loue must come to him,
And he has a worth deserues it, were it dearer.

div.stage: Enter a friend of the Colonells, and another of Captaine Agers.

sp.speaker: Colo. Frien.
sp.l: I must not giue way too't,

sp.speaker: Col. Frie.
sp.l: Compare young Captaine Ager, with the Colonel,

lg.l: Yong? why, doe you make youth stand for an imputation: that which you now produce for his disgrace,
Infers his noblenes, that being young
Should haue an anger more enclind to courage
And moderation then the Colonell:
A vertue as rare as chastety in youth.
And let the cause be good; (conscience in him
Which euer crownes his acts, and is indeed,
Valours prosperity) he dares then as much,
As euer mad him famous that you pleade for;

sp.speaker: Russ.
sp.p: Heres noble youths, belike some wench has crost'em, and now they know not what to doe with their blood.

div.stage: Enter the Colonell and Captaine Agar.

sp.speaker: Colo.
sp.l: So serious at your game, come, come, the quarrell,

sp.speaker: Col. fri.
sp.l: Bleed, where, pish, a little scratch by chance sir,

lg.l: What need this nicenes, when you know so wel
That I must know these things, and truly know 'em,
Your daintines makes me but more impatient,
This strange concealement frets me.
Words did passe
Which I was bound to answer, as my opinion
And loue instructed me, and should I take in generall fame,
Into 'em, I thinke I should commit no error in't,

sp.speaker: Colo.
sp.l: What words sir, and of whom,

lg.l: This gentleman.
Paralelld Captaine Agers worth with yours,
It was a thing I could nor listen to
With any patience.
What should aile you sir,
There was little wrong done to your friend i'that,
I said so, friend.
And I suppose that you'le esteeme it so;
Why sis? twixt friend, and friend,
There is so euen and leuell a degree
It will admit of no superlatiue.
Good sir giue mee leaue, in termes of manhood?
What can you dispute more questionable?
You are a captaine sir, I giue you all your due,
And you are a Colonell, a title
Which may include within it many captaines,
Yet sir, but throwing by those titular shaddows,
Which ad ne substance to the men themselues;
And take them vncompounded, man and man;
They may be so with faire equallity,
And you haue a Beard sir.
Virginity and marriage are both worthy,
And the positiue puritie there are some
Haue made the nobler.
I shrinke not, he that goes the formost,
May be oretaken.
In an euen ballance sir, a beard put in
Giues but a small aduantage: man and man
And lift the scales,
Patience shalbe my curse
If it tide me further;
How now Gallants?
Beleeue me then, I must giue aime no longer,
Can words beget swords and bring um forth, ha?
Come they are abortiue propagations;
Hide 'um for shame, I had thought Souldiers
Had bin musicall; would not strike out of time,
But to the consort of Drum, Trumps and Fife.
Tis madman-like to daunce without musique.
And most vnpleasing showes to the beholders,
A Lydian ditty to a Dorick note
Friends embrace with steele hands? fie, it meets to hard,
I must haue those encounters heere debar'd,
Shall I loose heere what I haue safe brought home
Through many dangers?
My fame,
Life of the life, my reputation,
Death? I am squar'd and measur'd out, my heights
Depths, breadth, all my dimensions taken,
Sure I haue yet beyond your Astralobe
A spirit vnbounded;
Tush, all this is weighing fire, vaine & fruitles,
The further it runnes into argument
The further plung'd, beseech you no more on't,
I haue a little claime, sir, in your blood
As neare as the brother to your mother,
If that may serue for power to moue your quiet
The rest I shall make vp with curtesie
And an Vncles loue.

sp.speaker: Russ.
sp.l: But! Ile haue no more shooting at these buts,

sp.speaker: Colo:
sp.l: Wee'le to pricks, when he please,

lg.l: You roue all still
Sir, I haue no motiue proofe to disgest
Your raisd choller back into temperate blood,
But if you'le make mine age a counsellor
(As all ages haue hitherto allow'd it)
Wisdome in men growes vp as yeares encrease,
You shall make me blessed in making peace,
And doe your iudgement right,
In peace at home
Gray hayres are Senators: but to determine
Soldiers and their actions;
Tis peace heere sir,
And see, heere comes a happy Interim,
Here enters now a Sceane of louing armes;
This couple will not quarrell so;
Be aduisd Sir,
This gentleman Fitzallen is your kinsman,
You may' orethrow his long labord fortunes
With one angry minut, tis a rich churle
And this his sole inheritrix, blast not
His hopes with this tempest,
It shall calme me,
All the townes coniurers and their Daemons
Could not haue layd my spirit so,
Worthy Cuz
I gratulate your faire returne to peace
Your swift fame was at home long before you;
It meetes (I hope) your hapy fortunes heere
And I am glad int, I must salute your ioyes, cuz,
With a soulders encounter Kisses her.
Worthy Captaine Ager,
I hope my kinsman shortly,—
You must come short indeed,
Or the length of my deuise will be ill shrunke,
Why now it showes finely, Ile tell you, sir,
Sir, nay sonne, I know i'th end, twill be so,
Hope? nay tis past all hope, sonne,
Heere has beene such a stormy incounter,
Betwixt my cozen Captaine and this braue Colonell
About I know not what, nothing indeed,
Competitions, degrees and comparatiues
Of Soldiership: but this smooth passage
Of loue has calm'd it all, come Ile hau't found,
Let me see your hearts combined in your hands,
And then I will beleeue the league is good,
It shall be the grapes if we drinke any blood.
I haue had none,
My blood has not yet rose to a quarrell,
Nor haue you had cause,
No cause of quarrell?
death? if my father should tell me so:
Faith, I haue done, Cuz,
You doe too hastily beleeue mine anger,
And yet to say, deminiting vallour
In a soldier is no cause of quarrell.
Nay then Ile remoue the cause to kil th'effect,
Kinsman, Ile presse you too't, if either loue
Or consanguinity may moue you too't,
I must disarme you, though yeare a soldier,
Pray grant me your weapon, it shall be safe
At your regresse from my house, now I know
No words can moue this noble soldiers sword
To a man vndefenc't so, we shall parle,
And safely make all perfect friends agen,
To shew my will sir, accept mine to you,
As good not weare it as not dare to vse it.
Nay then sir, we will be all exampled.
Wee'le haue no Armes heere now but louers armes.
No seconds must begin a quarrell,
Take mine sir.
Why Law, what a fine Sun shines heere? these
clouds my breath has blowne into another Climate,
Ile be your armourers, they are not paun'd,
These were the fish that I did angle for,
I haue caught 'vm finely, now for my trick,
My proiect's lusty, and will hit the nick. Exit with weapons.
What ist a match beauty? I would now haue,
Aliance with my worthy Captaine Ager,
To knit our loues the faster; heeres witnes
Enough if you confirme it now.
Sir my voyce,
Was long since giuen, since that I gaue my hand,
That wish comes too late,
For I too soone feare my deliuery: (aside.)
My fathers hand stickes yet sir, you may now
Challenge a lawfull interest in his,
Hee tooke your hand from your enraged blood,
And gaue it freely to your opposite
My Cozen Ager, me thinks you should claime from him,
In the lesse quality of calmer blood,
To ioyne the hands of two diuided friends,
Euen these two that would offer willingly
Their owne embrace.
Troth, she instructs you well
Colonell: and you shall doe a louers part
worth one braue act of vallour.
Why, I did
misdoubt no scruple, is there doubt in it?
Faith sir, delaies, which at the least are doubts,
But heeres a constant resolution fixt,
Which we wish willingly he would accord to,
Tush he shall doo't, I will not be denyed,
Hee owes me so much in the recompence
of my reconcilement, Captaine Ager
You will take our parts aganst your vncle
In this quarrell?
I shall doe my best, sir,
Two denialls shall not repulse me, I loue
Your worthy kinsman and wish him mine, I know
He doubts it not.
Your qu.
Be sure you keep it, 'twill be spoken quickly.
Therefore watch it.

sp.speaker: Colo.
sp.l: Lets set on him all at once.

sp.speaker: Omnes,
sp.l: Sir, we haue a sute to you.

lg.l: On speaker may yet deliver, say, say,
I shall not dare to stand out against so many,
Faith sir heeres a brabling matter hangs on demurre,
I make the motion for all, without a fee
Pray you let it be ended this terme,
Ha, ha, ha.
Thats the rascalls qu, and he has mist it. a side.
What is it? what is it sir?
Why sir, here's a man;
And heer's a woman; y'are scholler good enough,
Put 'am togither; and tell me what it spells,

sp.speaker: Russ.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, theres his qu once agen,

sp.speaker: Seru.
sp.l: My maister laughes, that's his qu to mischiefe,

sp.speaker: Seru.
sp.l: Sir, theres a couple desire speedily to speake with you.

sp.speaker: Russ.
sp.l: A couple sir, of what, hounds, or horses?

lg.l: Men sir, gentlemen or yeomen, I know not which;
But the one sure they are

sp.speaker: Russ.
sp.l: Hast thou no other description of them.

lg.l: They come with commission, they say, sir to
tast of your earth: if they like it, they'le turne it into gunpouder.
Oh, they are Salt-peetermen, before mee
And they bring commission: the kings power indeed,
They must haue entrance, but the knaues will be brib'd,
Theres all the hope we haue in Officers,
They were too dangerous in a common wealth,
But that they will be very, well corrupted, necessary varlets,
By all faire meanes sir.
And with all speed sir giue vm very good words,
To saue my ground vnrauisht, vnbroke vp,
Mines yet a virgin earth: the worme hath not beene seene,
To wriggle in her chast bowells: and Ide be loth
A Gunpowder fellow should defloure her now.

sp.speaker: Colo.
sp.l: Our suit is yet delayd by this meanes sir,

lg.l: Alas I cannot help it, these fellowes gone
(As I hope I shall dispatch vm quickly)
A few Articles shall conclude your suite,
Who? Mr. Fitzallen: the onely man
That my adoption aymes at.

sp.speaker: Russ.
sp.l: You are welcome sir for ought I know yet,

sp.speaker: 2. Ser.
sp.l: We come to take a view and tast of your ground, sir,

lg.l: I had rather feed you with better meat, Gentlemen,
But doe your pleasures, pray:

sp.l: This is our pleasures, we arrest you, sir, in the Kings name

sp.speaker: Colo.
sp.l: Our weapons, good sir furnish vs.

lg.l: Stay stay, Gentlemen, lets enquire the cause,
It may be but a trifle; a small debt,
Shall need no rescew heere.

sp.p: Sir betwixt three Creditors: Mr. Leach, Mr. Swallow, and Mr. Bonesuck, the debts are a thousand pounds.

lg.l: A thousand pounds?
Beshrow me a good mans substance.

sp.speaker: Colo.
sp.p: Good sir our weapons weele teach these varlets to walke in their owne parti-coulour'd Coates, that they may be distinguish't from honest men.

lg.l: Sir, attempt no rescue, hee's our prisoner,
you'le make the danger worse by violence.
A plague vpon your Gunpowder treason;
Yee quicke damb'd Varlets, is this your salt peter proouing,
Your tasting earth, would you might neuer feede better,
Nor none of your Catchpole tribe:
Our weapons good sir, weele yet deliuer him.
Pardon me sir,
I dare not suffer rescue heere,
At least not by so great an accessarie
As to furnish you; had you had your weapons,
But to see the Ill fate on't, my fine tricke Ifaith,
Let Beggers beware to loue Richmens Daughters,
I'le teach 'um the new morrice, I learn't it
My selfe of another carefull Father.
I ith field,
But not in the Citty, sir, if this Gentleman
Will be one, wee'le easily admit the second.
Who I? sir, pray pardon me, I am wrongd,
Very much wrongd in this, I must needs speake it,
Sir, you haue not dealt like an honest Louer,
With me nor my child, heere you boaste to mee
Of a great reuenew, a large substance
Wherein you would endow & state my daughter,
Had I mist this, my opinion yet
Thought you a frugall man, to vnderstand,
The sure wardes against all necessities,
Boldly to defend your wife and Family,
To walke vnmuffled, dreadlesse of these fleshhookes,
Euen in the daring'st streets through all the Citty,
But now I find you a loose Prodigall,
A large vnthrift, a whole thousand pound?
Come from him girle, his inside is not found?
Sir I am wrongd,
These are malitious plots,
Of some obscure enemies that I haue,
These debts are none of mine.
I all say so,
Perhaps you stand ingag'd for other men,
If so you doe, you must then cal't your owne,
The like arrerage doe I run into
Should I batle you; But I haue vow'd against it,
And I will keepe my vowes: that's religious.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: All this is nothing so sir.

lg.l: Nothing so?
By my faith it is sir, my vowes are firme,
I neither owe these debts,
Nor engag'd for others.
The easier is your liberty regain'd,
These appeare proofes to me,
Liberty sir?
I hope youle not see him goe to Prison,
I do not meane to beare him company
So far: but Ile see him out of my doores,
Oh sir, let him goe to Prison, 'tis a Schoole
To tame wild bloods, heele be much better fort,
In prison,
Beleeue it many an honest man lies in prison,
Else all the keepers are knaues,
They told me so themselues.
Sir, I doe now suspect you haue betraid him,
And vs to cause vs to be weaponlesse,
If it be so y'are a blood suckng Churle,
One that was born in a great frost, when charity
Could not stir a finger, and you shall dye
In heate of a burning feauer i'th Dog. dayes,
To begin your hell to you, I haue said your grace for you,
Now get you to supper as soone as you can,
Pluto the Maister of the house is set already,

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Sir you doe wrong mine Vncle.

lg.l: Poxe on your Vncle,
And all his kin, if my Kinsman mingle
No blood with him.

sp.speaker: Colo.
sp.l: Foule mouth'd I will be, th'art the son of a whore,

lg.l: Ha! Whore! plagues and furies Ile thrust that backe,
Or pluck thy heart out after, sonne of a whore?

sp.speaker: Colo.
sp.l: On thy life Ile proue it,

lg.l: Death I am naked,
Vncle, Ile giue you my left hand, for my sword,
To arme my right with; Oh this fire wil flame me
Into prsent ashes,
Sir, giue vs Weapons,
We aske our owne, you will not rob vs of them?
No sir, but still restraine your furies heere,
At my dore Ile giue you them, nor, at this time
My Nephewes, a time will better suit you,
And I must tell you sir, you haue spoke swordes,
And 'gainst the law of armes poyson'd the blades
And with them wounded the reputation
Of an vnblemisht woman: would you 'were out of my dores.
Poxe on your dores, and let it run all your house ore,
Giue me my sword.
Yes better prouided, to spur thee more,
I do repeat my words Son of a Whore. Exit with his friend.
Come sir, 'tis no worse then 'twas:
You can doe nothing now. Exit Capt. and his friend.

sp.speaker: Russ.
sp.l: No, Ile bar him now, away with that begger, Exit.

lg.l: Good sir, let this perswade you for two minutes stay,
At this prise (I know) you can wait all day.

sp.speaker: 1. Ser.
sp.l: You know the Remora that stayes our ship alwaies.

lg.l: Your ship sinkes many when this hold lets goe,
Oh my Fitzallen what is to be done,
To be still thine is all my part to be,
Whether in freedome or captiuity,

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.l: But art thou so ingag'd as this pretends?

lg.l: By heau'n, sweet Iane 'tis all a hellish plot
Your cruell smiling father all this while,
Has candied o're a bitter pill for me,
Thinking by my remoue to plant some other,
And then let goe his fangs.
Plant some other?
Thou hast too firmely stampt me for thine owne,
Euer to be rast out, I am not currant
In any others hand; I feare too soone
I shall discouer it.
Let come the worst,
Binde but this knot with an vnloosed line,
I will be still thine owne..

sp.speaker: 1. Ser.
sp.l: My watch has gone two minutes M.

sp.speaker: Fitz
sp.l: It shall not be renew'd, I goe sir, farewell.

lg.l: Farewell, wee both are prison'd, though not togeither:
But heers the difference in our luckelesse chance.
I feare mine owne, wish thy deliuerance.
Our hearts shall hourely visit, ile send to thee, Exit Fitz, with Officers
Then tis no prison where the mind is free.
So, let him goe, now wench I bring thee ioyes,
A faire sun-shine after this angry storme:
It was my pollicie to remoue this begger:
What shall rich men wed their onely daughters
To two faire suites of cloathes? and perhaps yet
The poore Taylor is vnpaid; no, no my gitle,
I haue a lad of thousands comming in;
Suppose he haue more wealth then wit to guid it:
Why, theres thy gaines, thou kep'st the keies of all
Disposest all: and for generation,
Man does most sildome stampe 'um from the braine,
Wisemen begets fooles, and fooles are the fathers
To many wise Children. Histeron, Proteron,
A great scholler may be get an Ideot,
And from the plow tayle may come a great scholler:
Nay, they are frequent propogations.
Ha? not well my girle?
Thou shalt haue a Physitian then,
The best that gold can fetch vpon his footecloath,
Thou knowest my tender pitty to thee euer,
Want nothing that thy wishes can instruct thee
To call for, 'fore mee, and thou look'st halfe ill indeed,
But Ile bring one within a day to thee
Shall rouse thee vp: for hees come vp already,
One M. Chaugh a Cornish Gentleman:
Ha's as much land of his owne fee-simple,
As a Crow can flie ouer in halfe a day:
And now I thinke on't, at the Crow at Algate
His lodging is, He shall so stir thee vp,
Come, come, be cheard, thinke of thy preferment,
Honour and attendance, these wil bring thee health
And the way to 'um is to clime by wealth. Exeunt.

div.head: Actus Secundus, Scaena primae.

lg.l: The Sonne of a Whore?
There is not such another murdring piece
In all the stocke of Calumny: it kils
At one report two reputations,
A mothers and a Sonnes: if it were possible
That soules could fight after the bodies fell,
This were a quarrell for 'em; he should be one indeed
That neuer heard of heauens ioyes or hels torments
To fight this out: I am too full of conscience,
Knowledge and patience, to giue Iustice too't,
So carefull of my Eternity, which consists
Of vpright actions: that vnlesse I knew
It were a truth I stood for, any Coward
Might make my breast his footepace, & who liues
That can assure the truth of his conception,
More then a mothers carriage makes it hopefull.
And i'st not miserable valour then,
That man should hazard all vpon things doubtfull
Oh ther's the cruelty of my foes aduantage,
Could but my soule resolue my cause were iust,
Earth's mountaine, nor seas surge should hide him from mee,
Ee'ne to hells threshold would I follow him,
And see the slanderer in before I left him,
But as it is it feares me, and I neuer
Appeard too conscionably iust till now:
My good oppinion of her life and Vertues,
Bids me goe on: and faine would I be ruld by't,
But when my iudgement tels me shees but woman,
Whose fraile to let in death to all mankinde,
My valour shrinkes at that, certaine shees good,
There onely wants but my assurance in't,
And al things then were perfect how I thirst for't,
Heere comes the onely shee that could resolue,
But 'tis too vild a question to demand indeed.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Sonne l'ue a suite to you.

lg.l: That may doe well.
To me good Madame, you're most sure to speed in't.
Beet i'my power to grant it,
Tis my loue
Makes the request, that you would neuer parte
From England more,
With all my heart tis graunted,
I'me sure Ime i'th way neuer to part from't,

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Where left you your deare friend the Colonel?

sp.speaker: Capt
sp.l: Oh the deare Colonel, I should meete him soone,

lg.l: Oh faile him not then, hees a Gentleman
The same and reputation of your time
Is much engadg'de to.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.l: Yes, and you knew all mother.

lg.l: I thought I'de knowne so much of his faire goodnes,
More could not haue bin look't for.
O yes, yes Madam.
And this his last exceeded all the rest.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: For gratitudes sake let me know this, I pre thee.

lg.l: Then thus, and I desire your censure freely,
Whether it appeard not a strange noble kindnes in him.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Trust me I long to hear't,

lg.l: You know hees hasty,
That by the way.
So are the best conditions
Your Father was the like.
I begin now
To doubt me more, why am not I so too then,
Blood followes blood through forty generations,
And I'ue a slow pac't wrath, a shrewd Dilemma,

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Well, as you were saying sir,

lg.l: Marry thus good Madame,
There was in company a foule mouth'd villaine, stay, stay,
Who should I liken him to, that you haue seene,
He comes so neere one that I would not match him with,
Faith iust a'th Colonels pitch, hees nere the worse man,
Vserers haue bin compard to Magistrates,
Extortiners to Lawyers, and the like,
But they all proue nere the worse men for that,

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: That's bad enough, they need not,

lg.l: This rude fellow,
A shame to all humanity or manners,
Breaths from the rottenes of his gall and mallice,
The foulest staine that euer mans same blemisht,
Part of which fell vpon your honor Madame,
Which heighthend my affliction.
The Colonel soone inrag'd,
(As hee's all touch-wood)
Takes fire before me, makes the quarrell his,
Appoynts the Field, my wrath could not be heard
His was so high pitcht, so gloriously mounted,
Now whats the friendly feare, that fights within mee,
Should his braue noble Fury vndertake,
A cause that were vniust in our defence,
And so to loose him euerlastingly,
In that darke depth where all bad quarrells sinke,
Neuer to rise againe, what pitty twere,
First to dye heere and neuer to dye there.
Why whats the quarrel, speake sir: that should raise
Such fearefull doubt, my honour bearing part ou't:
The words what ere they were:
Thou lyest, & were my loue ten thousand times more to thee,
Which is as much now, as ere mothers was,
So thou shouldst feele my anger. Do'st thou call
That quarrel doubtfull; where are all my merites, Strikes him.
Not one stand vp to tell this man his error.
Thou might'st as well bring the Sun's truth in question,
As thy birth or my honour.
Now blessings crown you for't,
It is the ioyful'st blow that ere flesh felt.
Nay stay, stay sir, thou art not left so soone,
This is no question to be slighted of,
And at your pleasure closde vp fayre agen,
As though you'de neuer toucht it, no honour doubted,
Is honour deepely wounded, and it rages
More then a common smart, being of thy making.
For thee to feare my truth, it kils my comfort,
Where should fame seeke for her reward, when he
That is her owne by the great tye of bloud,
Is fardest of in bounty, O poore goodnes!
That onely pay'st thy selfe with thy owne works,
For nothing else looks towards thee. Tell me pray,
Which of my louing cares dost thou requite
With this vilde thought? which of my prayers or wishes?
Many thou owest me for, this seauen year hast thou known me
A widdow, onely married to my vow:
Thats no small witnesse of my faith and loue
To him that in life was thy honord Father,
And liue I now to know that good mistrusted.
No, t'shall appeare that my beliefe is cherefull,
For neuer was a mothers reputation
Noblyer defended, tis my ioy and pride,
I haue a firme to bestow vpon it.
'Twere too bold, and soone yet
To craue forgiuenesse of you. I will earne it first,
Dead or aliue, I know I shall enioy it.
My ioyes beyond expression:
I do but thinke how wretched I had been,
Were this anothers quarrell, and not mine.
Mine! Thinke me not so miserable,
Not to be mine: then were I worse then abiect,
More to be loathde then villnes; or sins dunghill:
Nor did I feare your goodnes (faithfull Madame)
But came with greedy ioy to be confirmde in't,
To giue the nobler onset, then shines valour,
And admiration from her fix't Sphere drawes,
When it comes burnisht with a righteous cause,
Without which I'me ten fadomes vnder coward,
That now am ten degrees aboue a man,
Which is but one of vertues easiest wonders.
But pray stay; all this while I vnderstood you,
The Colonel was the man
Yes, hee's the man,
The man of iniury, reproach and slander,
Which I must turne into his soule again.
The villaine did it:
Thats not so strange;— your blessing and your leaue

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Come, come, you shall not goe.

lg.l: Not goe; were death
Sent now to summon me to my Eternity,
I'de put him off an howre: why the whole world
Ha's not chains strong inough to bind me from't:
The strongest is my Reuerence to you,
Which if you force vpon me in this case;
I must be forc'st to breake it.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.l: In any thing commaund me but in this Madame.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Lasse, I shall loose him, you'le heare me first.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Youl'e neuer heare me more then.

lg.l: Come backe I say:
You may well thinke theres cause I call so often.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: So much, you must not goe.

lg.l: I know a reason for't,
Which I could wish you'd yeeld to, & not know
If not, it must come forth. Faith, do not know,
And yet obey my will.
Why I desire
To know no other then the cause I haue,
Nor should you wish it, if you take your iniury
For one more great, I know the world includes not.
Yes, one that makes this nothing,— yet be rulde,
And if you vnderstand not, seeke no further.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.l: I must, for this is nothing.

lg.l: Then take all,
And if amongst it you receiue that secret
That will offend you, though you condemn mee,
Yet blame your selfe a little, for perhaps
I would haue made my reputation sound
Vpon an others hazards with lesse pitty;
But vpon yours I dare not.
I dare not,
'T was your owne seeking; this,
If you meane euilly
I cannot vnderstand you, nor for all the riches
This life has, would I.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.l: Why, your goodnes, that I ioy to fight for.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: In that you neither right your ioy nor me.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.l: What an ill Orator has vertue got here?
Why, shal I dare to thinke it a thing possible

lg.l: Oh fearefully!
As much as you come to.
Oh silence, couer me.
Iue felt a deadlier wound then man can giue me, false?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: I was betraide to a most sinfull howre.
By a corrupted soule I put in trust once.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.l: Where is shee? let me pay her.

lg.l: Nay then sh'as all her wages:
False, do not say't, for honors goodnes doe not,
You neuer could be so, he I calde Father,
Deserud you at your best, when youth & merit
Could boast at highest in you, y'ade no grace,
Or vertue that he matcht not, no delight
That you inuented but he sent it crownde
To your full wishing soule.

sp.speaker: Cap.

lg.l: Oh, were you so vnhappy to be false,
Both to your selfe and me, but to me chiefly,
What a dayes hope is here lost, and with it
The ioyes of a iust cause. Had you but thought
On such a noble quarrell, you'd ha dyed
Ere you'd ha yeelded, for the sins hate first,
Next for the shame of this howres cowardize:
Curst be the heate that lost me such a cause,
A worke that I was made for. Quench my spirit,
And out with honors flaming lights within thee:
Be darke and dead to all respects of manhood,
I neuer shall haue vse of valour more:
Put off your vow for shame, why should you hoarde vp
Such Iustice for a barren widdowhood,
That was so iniurious to the faith of wedlocke. Exit Lady.
I should be dead, for all my lifes works ended,
I dare not sight a stroke now, nor engadge
The noble resolution of my friends,

sp.stage: Enter two friends of Captaine Agers.

lg.l: That were more vilde. Their here, kill me my shame,
I am not for the fellowship of honour.
Captaine, fie come sir, we haue been seeking for you
very late to day, this was not wout to be,
Your enemies ith field,

sp.speaker: 2 Friend.
sp.l: Good faith sir y'aue a royall quarrell on't,

lg.l: Yes, in some other Country, Spaine or Italy.
It would be held so.

sp.speaker: 1 Friend.
sp.l: How, and ist not here so?

lg.l: Tis not so contumeliously receiude
In these parts, and you marke it.
Not in these?
Why prithee what is more, or can be?
Yes,
That ordinary Commotioner the lye
Is Father of most quarrels in this Clymate,
And held here capitall, and you go to that.
But sir, I hope you will not go to that,
Or change your owne for it, Sonne of a Whore,
Why theres the Lye downe to posterity.
The lye to brithe, the lye to honesty,
Why would you cussen you selfe so, and beguile
So braue a cause, Manhoods best Master peece,
Doe you euer hope for one so braue agen.
Consider then the man Colonell,
Exactly worthy, absolutely noble,
How euer spleene and rage abuses him:
And tis not wel, nor manly to pursue
A mans infirmity.
O miracle!
So hopefull, valiant and compleate a Captaine,
Possest with a tame deuill, come out, thou spoilest
The most improude yong souldier of seuen kingdoms,
Made Captaine at nineteene, which was deserude
The yeare before, but honor comes behind still,
Come out I say, this was not wont to be,
That spirit neuer stood in need of prouocation,
Nor shall it now. Away sir.

sp.speaker: 1. F.
sp.l: By Manhoods reuerend honor but we must.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.l: I will not fight a stroake.

lg.l: O blasphemy
To sacred valour!

sp.speaker: 1. Friend.
sp.l: Pardon this trayterous slumber, clogd with euils.

div.stage: Giue Captaines rather wiues then such tame diuels.

lg.l: Nay Master, you must not be couer'd to me,
The Patient must ope to the Physitian
All her dearest sorrowes: Art is blinded else,
And cannot shew her misticall effects.
Can Art be so dimsighted, learned sir?
I did not thinke her so in capacious:
You traine me (as I guesse) like a Coniurer,
One of our fiue Oraculous wizards,
who from the helpe of his Examinant,
By the neare guesse of his suspition
Appoints out the thiefe by the marks he tels him:
Haue you no skill in Phisiognomie?
what colour (sayes your coat) is my disease?
I am vnmarried, and it cannot be yellow,
If it be Mayden greene, you cannot misse it.
I cannot see that vacuum in your bloud:
But Gentlewoman, if you loue yourselfe,
Loue my aduise, be free and plaine with me,
where lyes your griefe?
Where lyes my griefe indeed?
I cannot tell the truth where my griefe lyes,
But my Ioy's imprison'd.
Lord, what plaine questions you make problemes of,
Your Art is such a regular high way
That put you out of it, and you are lost:
My heart is imprison'd in my body, sir:
Theres all my ioy, and my sorrow too
Lyes very neere it.
They are bad adiuncts,
Your ioy and griefe lying so neare together,
Can propagate no happy issue, remoue
The one (and let it be the worst) your griefe,
If you'le propose the best vnto your ioy.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.l: why, now comes your skill: what physicke for it?

sp.speaker: Phis.
sp.l: Now I haue found you out, you are in loue.

lg.l: I thinke I am, what your appliance now?
Can all your Paracelsian mixtures cure it,
'T must be a Surgeon of the Ciuill Law,
I feare that must cure me.
Gentlewoman,
If you knew well my heart, you would not bee
So circuler, the very common name
Of Physitian might reproue your nicenesse,
wee are as secret as your Confessors,
And as firme oblig'd, tis a fine like death
For vs to blab.
I will trust you, yet sir,
I had rather doe it by Atturney to you,
I else haue blushes that will stop my tongue
Haue you no friend so friendly as your selfe
Of mine owne Sexe, to whom I might impart
My sorrowes to you at the second hand.
why law, there I hit you, & be confirmde,
Ile giue you such a bosome counsellour,
That your own tong shall be sooner false to you,
Make your selfe vnready, and be naked to her:
Ile fetch her presently. Exit Physitian.
I must reueale
My shame will else take tongue, & speake before
Tis a necessity impulsiue driues me: me,
Oh my hard fate, but my more hard father,
That Father of my fate, a father said I?
What a strange Paradoxe I run into,
I must accuse two fathers of my fate
And fault, a reciprocall generation,
The father of my fault would haue repairde,
His faulty issue, but my Fates Father hinders it:
Then Fate and fault, where euer I begin,
I must blame both, and yet 'twas loue did sinne.

div.stage: Enter Physician, and Anne his sister.

lg.l: Looke you Mistres, heres's your closer put in,
What you please, you euer keep the key of it,
With all my heart,
I will be more then mine eares length from you.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.l: You hold some indeared place with this Gent.

lg.l: Hee's my brother forsooth, I his creature,
He does command me any lawfull office
Eyther in act or counsell.
I must not doubt you,
Your brother ha's protested secresie,
And strengthned me in you: I must lay ope
A guilty sorrow to you: I am with child,
Tis no blacke Swan I show you, these spots sticke
Vpon the face of many goe for maides,
I that had face ynough to do the deed,
Cannot want tongue to speake it: but tis to you,
Whom I accept my helper.
Mistris, tis lock't
Within a Castle that's inuincible,
It is too late to wish it were vndone.
I haue scarce wish within my selfe so strong
For vnderstand me, tis not all so ill,
As you may yet conceit it: this deed was done
When heauen had witness to the Iugall knot,
Onely the barren ceremonie wants.
Which by an aduerse Father is abridged.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.l: Would my pitty could helpe you.

lg.l: Your counsell may.
My Father yet shootes widest from my sorrow,
And with a care indulgent seeing me chang'd
From what I was, sends for your good brother
To finde my griefe, and practise remedy:
You know it, giue it him, but if a fourth
Be added to this counsell: I will say
Ye 'are worse then you can call me at the worst.
At this aduantage of my reputation.
I will reuiue a reputation,
That women long has lost, ile keepe counsell.
Ile onely now oblige my teeth to you,
And they shall bite the blabber if it offer
To breath on an offending syllable.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.l: I trust you, go, whisper, here comes my Father.

lg.l: Sir. you are welcome, more and most welcome,
All the degrees of welcome: thrice welcome sir.

sp.speaker: Chaw.
sp.p: Ile shew her the Cornish hug, sir,— I haue kist you now sweet heart, and I neuer doe any kindnesse to my friendes, but I vse to hitte'am in the teeth with it presently.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: My name is Trimtram forsooth, looke what my master does, I vse to doe the like.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.p: You are deceiu'd, sir, I am not this Gentlewomans seruant, to make your courtesie equall.

sp.speaker: Chaw.
sp.p: You doe not know me Mistresse.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: No indeed, I doubt I shall learne too soone.

sp.speaker: Chaw.
sp.p: My name is Chawgh, a Cornish Gentleman, my mans mine owne countriman too yfaith: I warrant, you tooke vs for some of the small Islanders.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: I did indeed, betweene the Scotch and Irish.

sp.speaker: Chaw.
sp.p: Red-shankes: I thought so by my truth, no truely, we are right Cornish Diamonds.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Yes, we cut out quarrels, and breake glasses, where wee goe,

lg.l: If it be hidden from her Father, yet
His ignorance vnderstands well his knowledge,
For this (I guesse) to be some rich coxcombe
Hee'de put vpon his daughter,
Then only shee's beholding to out helpe
For the close deliuery of her burden,
Else all's ouerthrowne.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: And pray be faithfull in that. sir.

lg.l: Tush, we Physitians are the truest
Alchymists, that from the ore and drosse of sinne,
Can new distill a Maydenhead agen.

sp.speaker: Russ.
sp.l: How doe you like her sir?

sp.speaker: Chaw.
sp.p: Troth I doe like her sir in the way of comparison to any thing that a man would desire. I am as high as the Mount in loue with her already, and thats as far as I can go by land, but I hope to goe further by water with her one day.

lg.l: I tell you sir, she has lost some colour,
By wrastling with a peeuish sicknes now of late.

sp.speaker: Chaw.
sp.p: Wrastle? nay and she loue wrastling, Ile teach her a tricke to ouerthrow any peeuish sicknes in London, what ere it be.

lg.l: Well, she had a rich beauty though I say't,
Nor is it lost: a little thing repayres it.

sp.speaker: Chaw.
sp.p: Shee shall commaund the best thing that I haue in Middlesex, yfaith.

lg.l: Well sir, talke with her, giue her a relish
Of your good liking to her, you shall haue time
And free accesse to finish what you now begin,
What meanes my father? my loues vniust restraint,
My shame were it publisht, both together
Could not afflict me like this odious foole:
Now I see why he hated my Fitz-Allen.

sp.speaker: Chaw.
sp.p:
Sweet Lady, your father sayes you are a wrastler,
if you loue that sport, I loue you the better. I faith I loue it as well as I loue my meate after supper, tis indeed meate, drinke and cloth to me.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.l: Me thinkes it should teare your clothes, sir.

sp.speaker: Chaw.
sp.p: Not a rag yfaith: Trimtram hold my cloake,— Ile wrastle a fall with you now, Ile show you a tricke that you neuer saw in your life.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.l: Oh good sir for beare, I am no wrastler.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.l: Good sir take heed, you'le hurt the Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Chaw.
sp.p: I will not catch beneath the waste belieue it, I know fayre play,

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.l: Tis no womans exercise in London, sir.

sp.speaker: Chaw.
sp.p: I'le nere belieue that, the hug and the locke betweene man and woman, with a fayre fall, is as sweete an exercise for the body, as you'l desire in a sommers euening.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.l: Sir, the Gentlewoman is not well,

sp.speaker: Chaw,
sp.l: It may be you are a Physitian, sir.

sp.speaker: Chaw.
sp.p: I say then, and ile stand too't, three ounces of wrastling with two hippes, a yard of a greene gowne put together in the Intourne, is as good a medicine for the greene sicknesse as euer breathd.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Come sir, take your cloake agen, I see here wil be nere a match.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: A match? I'de rather bee matcht from a Muskets mouth, and shot vnto my death.

sp.speaker: Chaw,
sp.l: Ile wrastle with any man for a good supper.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: I marry sir, ile take your part there, catch that catch may.

lg.l: Sir, she is willing too't. There at my house,
She shall be priuate, and neare to my attendance,
I know you not mistrust my faithfull care,
I shall returne her soone and perfectly.
Take your charge sir, go with this gentleman (Iane)
But prithee looke well this way, ere thou go'st,
'Tis a rich Simplicity of great Estate:
A thing that will be rul'd, and thou shalt rule,
Consider of your sexes generall ayme,
That domination is a womans heauen.

sp.speaker: Chaw.
sp.p: I will part at Dartmouth with her, sir, Oh that thou didst but loue wrastling, I would giue any man three foiles on that condition.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: There's three sorts of men that would thanke you for 'um, eyther Cutlers, Fencers, or Players.

sp.speaker: Russ.
sp.p: Sir as I began, I end, wondrous welcome.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: What, will you go to schoole to day? you are enterd you know, and your quarterige runs on.

sp.speaker: Chaw.
sp.p: What? to the roaring schoole? pox on't, 'tis such a damnable noyse, I shall neuer attaine it neyther: I doe wonder they haue neuer a Wrastling Schoole, that were worth twenty of your fencing or dancing schooles.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Wel, you must learne to roare here in London, you'le neuer proceede in the reputation of Gallantrie else.

sp.speaker: Chaw.
sp.p: How long ha's Roaring been an exercise, thinkest thou Trimtram.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Euer since Guns came vp, the first was your roaring Meg

sp.speaker: Ch. Meg▪
sp.p: Then 'twas a woman was the first roarer:

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: I, a fire of her tuch-hole, 'that cost many a proper mans life since that time: and then the Lyons they learn't it from the Guns, liuing so neare 'um, then it was heard to the Banckeside, and the Beares they beganne to roare: then the boyes got it, and so euer since there haue beene a company of roaring boyes.

sp.speaker: Chaw.
sp.p: And how long will it last, thinkest thou?

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: As long as the Water runs vnder London Bridge, or Watermen at Westminster stayres.

sp.speaker: Chaw.
sp.p: Well, I will beginne to roare too, since it is in fashion, Oh Corineus, this was not in thy time, I should haue heard on't by the tradition of mine Ancestors (for I' me sure there were Chawghes in thy dayes) if it had beene so, when Hercules and thou wert on the Olimpicke mount together, then was wrastling in request.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: I, and that Mount is now the Mount in Cornwall. Corineus brought it thither vnder one of his arms, they say.

sp.speaker: Chaw.
sp.p: Oh Corineus my predecessor: that I had but liu'd in those dayes to see thee wrastle, on that condition I had dyed seuen yeare ago.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Nay, it should haue been a dozen at least, yfaith, on that condition. Exeunt.

div.head: Actus Tertius. Scaena Prima.
div.stage: Enter Captaine Ager with his two friends.

lg.l: Our Wils? our Loues, our Duties
To honord Fortitude: What wils haue we
But our desires to Noblenes and Merit?
Valours aduancement, and the sacred Rectitude
Due to a valourous cause.
War ha's his court of Iustice, that's the field,
Where all cases of Manhood are determinde,
And your case is no meane one.
True, then 'twere vertuous:
But mine is in extreames, fowle and vniust:
Well, now y'aue got me hither, y'are as far
To seeke in your desire, as at first minute:
For by the strength and honour of a vow,
I will not lift a finger in this quarrell.
How? not in this? be not so rash a sinnen:
Why sir, doe you euer hope to fight agen then
Take heede on't, you must neuer looke for that,
Why the vniuersall stocke of the Worlds iniury,
Will bee too poore to finde a quarrell for you:
Giue vp your right and title to desert, sir,
If you fayle vertue here, shee needes you not:
All your time after, let her take this wrong,
And neuer presume then to serue her more:
Bid farewell to the integrity of armes,
And let that honourable name of Souldier
Fall from you like a shiuered wreath of Lawrell
By Thunder strucke from a desertlesse forehead,
That weares anothers right by vsurpation.
Good Captaine, do not wilfully cast away
At one houre all the same your life ha's won:
This is your natiue seate, here you should seeke
Most to preserue it, or if you will doate
So much on life (poore life) which in respect
Of life in honour is but death and darknesse
That you will proue neglectfull of your selfe,
Which is to me too fearefull to imagine,
Yet for that vertuous Ladies cause (your mother)
Her Reputation, deere to Noblenesse
As grace to penitence, whose fayre memory,
Ee'n crowns fame in your issue, for that blessednes,
Giue not this ill place, but in spite of hell,
And all her base feates, be exactly valiant,
Why, well sayd, thetes fayre hope in that,
Another such a one.
Came they in thousands?
Tis all against you.
Then poore friendlesse merite,
Heauen be good to thee, thy professor leaues thee:

sp.stage: Enter Colonell and his two friends.
sp.l: Hee's comd, do but you draw, wee'le fight it for you.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.l: I know too much to grant that.

lg.l: O dead manhood!
Had euer such a cause so faynt a seruant?
Shame brand me if I do not suffer for him.
Iu'e heard sir, ya'ue bin guilty of much boasting,
For your braue earlines at such a meeting,
Y'aue lost the glory of that way this morning:
I was the first to day.
So were you euer.
In my respect sir.
I neuer thought on Victory our Mistres
With greater reuerence then I haue your worth,
Nor euer lou'd her better.

sp.p: Slight, I could knocke his braines about his heeles, mee thinkes.

lg.l: Successe in you has beene my absolute ioy,
And when I haue wisht content, I haue wisht your friendship.
Stay, let me but run him through the tongue a little,
Theres Lawyers bloud in't, you shal see foule geere streight

sp.l: Come you are as mad now, as hee's cowardous.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: I came not hither sir for an Encomium.

lg.l: No, the more Coxcombe he, that clawes the head
Of your vaine glory with't!
I came prouided
For Stormes and Tempests, and the fowlest Season
That euer Rage let forth, or blew in wildnesse
From the incensed prison of mans bloud.
Tis otherwise with me, I come with Mildnesse,
Peace, constant Amity, and calme Forgiuenes,
The weather of a Cristian and a friend.

sp.l: Giue me a valiant Turke, though not worth ten pence, rather.

lg.l: Yet sir, the world will iudge the iniury mine.
Insufferable mine, mine beyond iniury,
Thousands haue made a lesse wrong reach to hel,
I, and reioyc'st in his most endlesse vengeance,
(A miserable triumph, though a iust one)
But when I call to memory our long friendship
Me thinkes it cannot be too great a wrong.
That then I should not pardon, why should man,
For a poore hasty syllable or two,
(And vented onely in forgetfull fury)
Cheine all the hopes and riches of his soule
To the reuenge of that, dye, lost for euer:
For he that makes his last peace with his Maker
In anger, anger is his peace eternally:
He must expect the same returne againe,
Whose venture is deceitfull. Must he not sir?
I see what I must do, fairely put vp agen:
For here'le be nothing done, I perceiue that,
What shall be done in such a worthlesse businesset
But to be sorry, and to be forgiuen.
You sir to bring repentance, and I pardon.
If it be too much
To say Repentance: Call it what you please sir:
Chuse your owne world, I know you'r sorry for't, and thats as good.
I sorry? by fames honour, I am wrongd:
Doe you seeke for peace, and draw the quarrell larger?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.l: Then tis: I'me sorry that I thought you so.
A Captaine, I could gnaw his title of.

lg.l: Nor is it any misbecomming vertue, sir,
In the best manlines to repent a wrong,
Which made me bold with you.

sp.l: I could cuff his head off,
Pox on him, I could eate his buttocke bak't me thinks.

lg.l: So, once agen take thou thy peacefull rest then,
But as I put thee vp: I must proclaime
This Captaine here, both to his friends and mine,
That onely came to see fayre valour righted, Offers to go away.
A base submisiue coward; so I leaue him.
Oh, heauen has pittied my excessiue patience,
And sent me a cause: now I haue a cause:
A coward I was neuer:— Come you backe sir?
Tis such base mettell sir: 'twill not be taken,
It must home agen with you.

sp.l: Impossible, coward do more then bastard?

lg.l: I prethee mocke me not, take heed you do not,
For if I draw once more, I shall grow terrible,
And rage will force me doe what will grieue honour.
He smiles, dare it be he? what thinke you Gentlemen?
Your iudgements, shall I not be cussend in him?
This cannot be the man? why he was bookish,
Made an inuectiue lately against fighting,
A thing introth that mou'de a little with me,
Put vp a fowler contumely far
Then thousand cowards came to, & grew thankfull
Blessed remembrance in time of need?
I'de lost my honour else.
I neuer felt a more seuere necessity.
Then came thy excellent pitty.-. Not yet ready?
Haue you such confidence in my iust manhood:
That you dare so long trust me, and yet tempt me
Beyond the tolleration of mans vertue,
Why? would you be more cruel then your iniury?
Do you first take pride to wrong me, & then think me
Not worth your fury, do not vse me so:
I shall deceyue you then: sir, eyther draw,
And that not sleightingly, but with the care
Of your best preseruation; with that watchfulnes,
As you'd defend your selfe from circuler fire,
Your sins rage, or her Lord, this will require it,
Or you'le be too soone lost for I'ue an anger
Has gathered mighty strength against you: mighty;
Yet you shall find it honest to the last,
Noble and Fayre.
I'le ventur'te once agen.
And if't be but as true, as it is wondrous,
I shall haue that I come for; Your leaue Gent.
If he should doo't indeed, & deceiues al now:
Stay, by this hand he offers; fights yfaith.
Fights: by this light he fights sir.
Why let it passe, and 'twas, I'me sure, t'was somwhat,
Whats that now.
O goe to then,
I knew 'twas not farre off: What a worlds this?
Is coward a more stirring meat then bastard, my Masters?
Put in more egges for shame when you get children,
And make it true Court custard.— Ho? I honor thee:
Tis right and fayre, and he that breathes against it,
He breathes against the iustice of a man,
And man to cut him off: tis no iniustice.
Thanks, thanks, for this most vnexpected noblenes.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Truth neuer fayles her seruant, sir, nor leaues him With the dayes shame vpon him.

lg.l: Th'ast redeemde
Thy worth to the same height 'twas first esteemde.
Alasse, how is it sir: giue vs some hope
Of your stay with vs: Let your spirit bee seene
Aboue your fortune, the best fortitude
Ha's been of Fate ill friended: Now force your Empire,
And raigne aboue your bloud, spite of deiection,
Reduce the Monarchie of your abler mind,
Let not flesh streighten it.
Oh, iust Heauen has found me ,¹
And turnde the strings of my too hasty Iniuries
Into my owne bloud, I pursude my ruine,
And vrgde him past the patience of an Angell.
Could mans reuenge extend beyond mans life:
This would ha' wak't it, If this flame will light me
But till I see my sister: tis a kinde one.
More I expect not from't, Noble deseruer:
Farewell most valiant, and most wrong'd of men, Exeunt, led by them.
Do but forgiue me, & I am Victor then.

div.stage: Enter Physitian, Iane, Anne, Dutch Nurse with the child.

lg.l: Sweet Fro, to your most indulgent care,
Take this my hearts ioy, I must not tell you,
The valew of this iewell in my bosome.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: Dat you may vell. sir, der can niet forstoore you.

lg.l: Indeed I cannot tell you, you know Nurse,
These are aboue the quantity of prise,
Where is the glory of the goodliest trees
But in the fruit and branches? The old stocke
Must decay, and sprigs, syens such as these
Must become new stockes from vs to glory,
In their fruitfull issue, so we are made
Immortall on by other.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: You spreke a most lieben fader, and Ick fall do de best of tender Nurses to dis Infant, my prettie Frokin.

lg.l: I know you will be louing, here sweet friend, Giue. money.
Heere's earnest of a large summe of loue and coyne.
To quit your tender care.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.l: I haue some reason too, Giues her money.
To purchase your deare care vnto this Infant.

sp.speaker: Nurs.
sp.p: You be de witnesse of de Baptime, dat is, as you spreken: de godimother, ick vell forstoor it so.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.l: Yes, I am the bad mother: If it be offence. Aside.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.l: I must be a little kinde too. Giues her money.

sp.speaker: Nurs.
sp.p: Much tankes to you all: dis child is much belouen: and Ick sall see much care ouer it.

lg.l: Farewell good sister: Show her the way forth,
I shall often visite you, kind Nurse.

sp.speaker: Nurs.
sp.l: You sall be velcome. Exeunt Ann and Nurse.

lg.l: Oh sir, what a friend haue I found in you?
Where my poore power shall stay in the requitall,
Your selfe must from your fayre condition
Make vp in meere acceptance of my will.
Oh, pray you vrge it not, we are not borne
For our selues onely, selfe loue is a sinne,
But in our louing donatiues to others,
Mans vertue best consists, loue all begets,
Without, all are adulterate and counterfeit.
Your boundlesse loue I cannot satisfie,
But with a mentall memory of your vertues,
Yet let me not ingage your cost withall,
Beseech you then take restitution
Of paines and bounty which you haue disburst
For your poore debter.
You will not offer it:
Doe not esteeme my loue so mercenary,
To be the hyre of coyne? Sure, I shall thinke
You doe not hold so worthily of me
As I wish to deserue.
Not recompence!
Then you will begger me with too much credit,
If not sufficient, you preserue my name,
Which I had forfeyted to shame and scorne:
Couer my vices with a vaile of loue,
Defend and keepe me from a fathers rage,
Whose loue yet infinite (not knowing this)
Might (knowing) turne a hate as infinite:
Sure he would throw me euer from his blessings,
And cast his curses on me: yes, further,
Your secresie keepes me in the state of woman:
For else what husband would chuse me his wife:
Knowing the honour of a Bride were lost.
I cannot number halfe the good you doe me,
In the concealde retention of my sinne,
Then make me not worse then I was before.
In my ingratitude, good sir.
Agen.
I shall repent my loue (if you'le so call't)
To be made such a Hackney, giue me coyne?
I had as leaue you gaue me poyson (Lady)
For I haue Art and Antidotes gain'st that,
I might take that, but this I will refuse.
Well you then teach me how I may requite you,
In some small quantity.
'T was that I look't for. Aside.
Yes, I will tell you Lady a full quittance,
And how you may become my Creditresse.
Indeed I will Lady,
Not in coyne, Mistris, for siluer though white,
Yet it drawes blacke lines: It shall not rule my palme
There to marke forth his base corruption:
Pay me agen in the same quality
That I to you tendred, thats loue for loue:
Can you loue me Lady? you haue confest
My loue to you.
Why faith then,
Pay me backe that way.
Tush, our meanings are better vnderstood
Then shifted to the tongue, it brings along
A little blabbing bloud into our cheekes,
That shames vs when we speake.
Fie, you doe, make not your selfe ignorant
In what you know, you haue tane forth the lesson
That I would read to you.
Sure then I need not,
Reade it agen, sir.
Yes, it makes perfect,
You know the way vnto Achillis speare,
If that hurt you, I haue the cure you see.
Come, y'are a good man, I do perceiue you:
You put a tryall to me, I thanke you,
Y'are my iust Confessor, and beleeue me,
I'le haue no further penance for this sinne,
Conuert a yeare vnto a lasting euer,
And call't Apollo's smile, 'twas onces then neuer.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.l: Pray you mistake me not, indeed I loue you.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.l: The deed that you haue done.

lg.l: Away, y'are a Blackamore, you loue me?
I hate you for your loue: Are you the man
That in your painted outside seem'd so white?
Oh, y'are a soule dissembling Hypocrite,
You sau'd me from a thiefe that your selfe might rob me,
Skin'd 'ore a greene wound to breed an vlcer.
Is this the practise of your Physicke Colledge?
Haue you yet vtter'd all your nicenesse forth?
If you haue more, vent it, certes I thinke
Your first grant was not yeelded with lesse paine,
If 'twere, you haue your prise, yeeld it againe.
Pray you, tell me sir, (I ask't it before)
Is it a practise 'mongst you Physitians.
Tush, thats a secret, We cast al waters.
Should I reueale, you would mistrust my counsell:
The Lawyer and Physitian here agrees
To women Clients they giue backe their fees,
And is not that kindnesse?
This for thy loue, Spits,
Out, outside of a man: thou Cynamon tree,
That but thy bark hast nothing good about thee
The Vnicorne is hunted for his horne,
The rest is left for carion: Thou false man.
Tha'st fisht with siluer hookes and golden baites:
But I'le auoyde all thy deceiuing sleights.
Doe what you lift, I will do somthing too:
Remember yet what I haue done for you,
Y'aue a good face now, but 'twill grow rugged.
Ere you grow old: old men will despise you:
Think on your Grandam Helen the fairest Queen
When in a new glasse she spyed her old face:
Shee (smiling) wept to thinke vpon the change,
Take your time, y'are craz'd, y'are an apple falne
From the tree, if you be kept long, you'le rot.
Study your answere well, yet I loue you.
If you refuse I haue a hand aboue. Exit Phys.

sp.speaker: Iane.

lg.l: Poyson thy selfe, thou soule Empoysoner:
Of thine owne practique drinke the Theorie.
What, a White Diuill haue I met withall?
What shall I doe? What do? i'st a question?
Nor shame, nor hate, nor feare, nor lust, nor force
(Now being too bad) shall euer make mee worse,

sp.l: What haue we here? a second spirit.

lg.l: Mistresse,
I am sent to you.
As you receyue it, my brother sent me,
And you know he loues you.
I heard say so;
But 'twas a false report.
Pray, pardon me, I must doe my message,
Who liues (commanded) must obey his Keeper.
I must perswade you to this act of woman.
Indeed of Strumpet,
He takes you at aduantage of your fall,
Seeing you downe before.
Hee's my brother Mistresse, & a curse on you
If ere you blesse him with that cursed deede,
Hang him, poyson him, he held out a Rose,
To draw the yeelding sence, which come to hand
He shifts, and giues a canker.
I, but Mistresse, now I consider it,
Your reputation lyes at his mercy,
Your fault dwels in his brest, say, he throw it out,
It will be knowne, how are you then vndone?
Thinke on't, your good name, and they are not to be solde,
In euery market, a good name's deare,
And indeed more esteemed then our actions,
By which wee should deserue it.
What? doe you shrinke at that?
Would you not weare one spot vpon your face,
To keepe your whole body from a leprosie,
Though it were vndiscouerd euer, hang him,
Feare him not. Horseleeches sucke out his corrupt bloud,
Draw you none from him, lesse it be pure and good.
Then yet I haue a friend; but thus exhort me,
And I haue still a collumbe to support me.
One fault Heauen soone forgiues, and tis on earth forgot,
The Moone her selfe is not without one spot. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter the Lady Ager, meeting one of her seruants.

lg.l: Now sir, where is he? speake, why comes he not?
I sent you for him; blesse this fellowes sences:
What has he seene? a soule nine houres entrancst,
Houering twixt hell and heauen, could not wake gastlier,
Not yet returne an answere? What say you sir?
Where is he?
He is gone Madame.
But as we heard, vnwillingly hee went
As euer bloud enforc't.

sp.speaker: 2 Ser.
sp.l: Madam, I feare, I ha said too much already.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: These men are both agreed, speake, whether went he?

sp.speaker: 2. Se.
sp.l: Why to— I would you'd thinke the rest your selfe Madame.

lg.l: There came two vrging Gentlemen,
That cal'd themselues his seconds, both so powerfull,
As tis reported they preuailde with him,
With little labour.
O hees lost, hees gone,
For all my paines, hee's gone; two meeting torrents
Are not so mercilesse as their two rages,
Hee neuer comes agen,— wretched affection.
Haue I belied my faith? iniur'd my goodnes?
Slaunderd my honour for his praeseruation?
Hauing but onely him: and yet no happier.
Tis then a iudgment plaine, truths angrie with mee,
In that I would abuse her sacred whitenesse,
For any wordly temporall respect:
Forgiue me then thou glorious womans vertue,
Admir'd where ere thy habitation is,
Especially in vs weake ones: Oh forgiue mee.
For tis thy vengeance this, to belie truth,
Which is so hardly ours, with such paine purchas'd
Fastings, and praiers, continence and care,
Misery must needs ensue: Let him not dye
In that vnchast beliefe of his false birth,
And my disgrace: What euer Angell guides him,
May this request be with my teares obtaind,
Let his soule know, my honour is vnstaind,
Runne, seeke, away, if there be any hope, Exeunt Seru.
Let me not loose him yet; when I thinke on him,
His deerenes, and his worth, it earnes me more,
They that know riches tremble to be poore.
My passion is not euery womans sorrow,
She must be truly honest feeles my greefe,
And onely knowne to One, if such there bee,
They know the sorrow that oppresseth mee. Exit.

div.head: Actus quartus, Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter the Colonels Second.. Vsher &c. with Chaugh and Trim.

sp.speaker: Second.
sp.p: Truth sir, I must needs blame you for a Trewant, hauing but one lesson read to you and neglect so soone: fye, I must see you once a day at least.

sp.speaker: Chaugh.
sp.p: Would I were whipt Tutor if it were not long of my man Trimtram here.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Who, of mee?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Tak't vpon the Trim. Ile giue the fiue shillings, 'as I am a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Ile see you whipt first: well, I will too; faith sir, I saw he was not perfect, and I was loth he should come before to shame himselfe.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: How? shame sir? is it a shame for Schollers to learne? Sir, there are great Schollers that are but slenderly read in our profession: sir, first it must be Oeconomicall, the Oecumenicall: shame not to practise in the house how to performe in the field: the naile that is driuen takes a little hould at the first stroke, but more at the second, and more at the third, but when tis home to the head, then tis firme.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: Faith I haue bene driuing it home to the head this two dayes.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: I helpt to hammer it in as well as I could too sir.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Well sir, I will heare you rehearse anon, meane time peruse the exemplary of my bills, and tell me in what language I shall rore a Lecture to you; or ile read to you the Mathematicall science of Roaring.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Is it Mathematicall?

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Oh sir, does not the windes roare? the Sea roare? the Welkin roare? indeed, most thinges doe roare by nature, and is not the knowledge of these thinges Mathematicall?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Pray prooceed sir. reads his bill

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: The names of the languages, the Sclanonian, Parthamenian, Barmeothian, Tiburnian, Wappinganian, or the moderne Londonian. Any man or woman that is desirous to roare in any of these languages, in a weeke they shall be perfect, if they will take paines; so let'um repaire into Holborne to the signe of the Cheat loafe.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: Now your bill speakes of that, I was wondring a good while at your signe, the loafe lookes very like bread ifaith, but why is it called the cheate loafe?

sp.speaker: Second.
sp.p: This house was sometimes a Bakers sir, that serued the Court where the bread is called cheate.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: I, I, twas a Baker that cheated the Court with bread.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Well sir, choose your languages: and your Lectures shal be read, betweene my Vsher and my selfe, for your better instruction, prouided your conditions be performed in the premisses beforesaid.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: Looke you sir, theres twenty pound in hand, and twenty more, I am to pay when I am allowed a sufficient Roarer.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: You speake in good earnest sir.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: Yes faith doe I Trimtram shall be my witnes.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Yes indeed sir, twenty pound is very good earnest.

sp.speaker: Vsher.
sp.p: Sir one thing I must tell you belongs to my place, you are the youngest Scholler, and till another comes vnder you, there is a certaine garnish belongs to the Schoole, for in our practise we grow to a quarrell: then there must be wine ready to make all friends, for thats the end of Roaring, 'tis valiant but harmelesse, and this charge is yours.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: With all my heart ifaith and I like it the better: because no blood comes on it, who shall fetch?

sp.speaker: 2. Roar.
sp.p: Ile be your Spanniell sir.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Bid Vapor, bring some Tobacco too,

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: Doe and heere's mony for't. Exit 2. Roarer.

sp.speaker: Vsher.
sp.p: No, you shall not, let me see the mony: so, Ile keepe it, and discharge him after the Combat, for your practise sake you and your man shall roare him out on't, (for indeed you must pay your debts so: for thats one of the maine ends of Roaring) and when you haue left him in a chafe, then Ile qualifie the Rascall.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: Content ifaith Trim. weele Roare the rusty Rascall out of his Tobacco.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: I and he had the best Craccus in London.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Obserue Sir, wee could now roare in the Slauonian Language, but this practise hath beene a little sublime: some hayres breadth or so aboue your Caput; I take it for your vse and vnderstanding both it were fitter for you to tast the moderne assault, only the Londonian Roare.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p:
Ifaith sir, that's for my purpose, for I shall vse all my
roaring heere in London: in Cornewall wee are all for wrastling, and I doe not meane to trauell ouer sea to roare there.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Obserue then sir, but it were necessary you took forth your tables, to note the most difficult poynts for the better assistance of your memory.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: Nay sir, my man and I keep two Tables.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: I sir, and as many trenchers, cattes meat and dogges meate enough.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Note sir,— Dost thou confront my Cyclops?

sp.speaker: Vsh.
sp.p: With a Briarean Brousted:

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: Cyclops.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Briarean.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: I know thee and thy lineall pedegree,

sp.speaker: Vsher.
sp.p: It is Collateral: as Brutus and Posthumus.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Brutus.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: Posthumus.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: False as the face of Heccate; thy sister is a—

sp.speaker: Vsh.
sp.p: What is my Sister Centaure?

sp.speaker: Seco.
sp.p: I say thy Sister is a Bronstrops.

sp.speaker: Vsh:
sp.p: A Bronstrops!

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: Tutor, Tutor, ere you goe any further, tell mee the English of that, what is a Bronsterops pray.

sp.speaker: Se.
sp.p: A Bronsterops is in English a Hippocrene.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: A Hippocrene, note it Trim. I loue to vnderstand the English as I goe.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Whats the English of Hippierene.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: Why Bronsterops?

sp.speaker: Vsh:
sp.p: Thou dost obtrect my flesh and blood,

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Agen, I denounce, thy sister is a fructifer,

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: What's that Tutor?

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: That is in English a Fucus or a Minotaure.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: A Minotaure:

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: A Fucus.

sp.speaker: Vsh.
sp.p: I say thy mother is a Callieut, a Panagron, a Duplar and a Sindicus.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Dislocate thy Bladud.

sp.speaker: Vsh.
sp.p: Bladud shall coniure, if his Daemons once appeare,

div.stage: Enter 2. Roarer with Wine, and Vapor with Tobacco.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Aduance thy respondency.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: Nay good gentleman, doe not fall out, a cup of wine quickly Trimtram.

sp.speaker: Vsh:
sp.p: See my steele hath a glister,

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: Pray wipe him, and put him vp againe good Vsher.

sp.speaker: Vsh.
sp.p: Sir at your request I pull downe the Flag of defiance.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Giue me a boule of Wine my fury shall bee quencht, heere Vsher.

sp.speaker: Vsh.
sp.p: I pledge thee in good friendship.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: I like the conclusion of Roaring very well ifaith.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: It has an excellent conclusion indeed, if the Wine be good, alwayes prouided.

sp.speaker: Seco.
sp.p: O the wine must be alwayes prouided be sure of that.

sp.speaker: Vsh.
sp.p: Else you spoyle the conclusion, and that you know crownes all.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: Tis much like wrestling ifaith: for wee shake hands ere we begin: now thats to avoid the Law, for then if hee throw him a furlong into the grownd, hee cannot recouer himselfe vpon him, because twas done in cold friendship.

sp.speaker: Seco.
sp.p: I beleeue you sir.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: And then we drinke afterwards, iust in this fashion, wrestling and Roaring are as like as can bee ifaith, euen like long sword and halfe pike.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Nay they are reciprocall if you marke it, for as there is a great Roaring at Wrestling: so there is a kinde of wrestling and contention at Roaring.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: True ifaith, for I haue heard 'um roare from the sixe windmilles to Islington: those haue beene great falls then.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Come, now a briefe rehersall of your other dayes lesson, betwixt your man and you, and then for to day wee break vp schoole.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: Come, Trimtram; if I be our Tutor, Ile be bold to looke in my tables, because I doubt I am scarse perfect.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Well, well, I will not see small faults

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: The wall,

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: The wall of mee, to thy kennell spannell,

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: Wilt thou not yeeld precedencie?

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: To thee, I know thee and thy broode

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p:
Knowst thou my brood, I know thy broode to,
thou art a Rooke;

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: The nearer a kinne to the Chaughes?

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: The Rookes a kin to the Chaughis?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Verie well maintain'd,

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: Dungcoer, thou liest,

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Lie, enucleate the kernell of thy scabberd,

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: Now if I durst draw my sword, twere valiant yfaith:

sp.speaker: Seco.
sp.p: Draw, draw, howsoeuer,

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: Haue some wine readie to make vs frends I pray you,

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Chaugh, I will make thee flie and roare,

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: I will roare if thou strik'st me,

sp.speaker: Seco.
sp.p: So tis ynoughe now conclude in wine, I see you will proue an excelent practitioner: wondrous well perform'd on both sides:

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: Heere Trimtram I drinke to thee,

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Is there not one Maister Chaugh heere,

sp.speaker: Vsh.
sp.p: This is the Gentleman sir;

sp.speaker: Seru.
sp.p: My maister, sir, your elected father in law, desires speedyly to speake with you:

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: Friend I will follow thee, I would thou hadst come a little soner, thou shouldest haue seene Roring sport yfaith,

sp.speaker: Seru.
sp.p: Sir Ile returne that you are following, Exit seruant

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: Doe so: Ile tell thee Tutor, I am to marry shortly, but I will deferre it a while till I can roare perfectly, that I may get the vpper hand of my wife on the wedding day, 'tmust be done at first or neuer.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: 'T will serue you to good vse in that sir.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: How lik'st thou this Whister?

sp.speaker: Vap.
sp.p: very valiantly ifaith sir,

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Tush, thou shalt see more by and by.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.p: I can stay no longer indeed sir, who paies mee for my Tobocco?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: How, pay for Tobacco, away ye sootie mouth'd piper: you rustie piece of Martlemas bacon, away.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Let me giue him a Marke for't.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p:
No Trimtram, doe not strike him, weele onely
roare out a curse vpon him.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Well, doe you begin then,

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: May thy Roule rot, and thy pudding drop in pieces, being sophisticated with filthy vrine.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: May Serieants dwell on either side of thee, to fright away thy two penny customers.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: And for thy penny ones, let them sucke thee drie.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: When thou art dead, maist thou haue no other sheets to be buried in but mouldie Tobacco leaues.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: And no strawings to sticke thy Carkas, but the bitter stalkes.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Thy mourners, all greazie Tapsters,

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: With foule Tobacco pipes in their hats in stead of rotten Rose mary: and last of all may my man and I liue to see all this perform'd and, to pisse reeking euen vpon thy graue

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: And last of all for mee, let this Epitaph bee remembred ouer thee.

lg.l: Here coldly now within is laid to rot,
A man that yesterday was piping hot:
Some sap he died by pudding, some by pricke,
Others by role and ball some lease, all sticke
Fast in censure, yet thinke it strange and rare,
(He liu'd by smoake, yet died for want of ayre)
But then the Surgeon said when he beheld him,
It was the burning of his Pipe that kild him.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: So, are you paid now whisler?

sp.speaker: Vap.
sp.p: All this is but smoake out of a stinking Pipe,

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: So, so, pay him now Usher.

sp.speaker: Sec:
sp.p: Doe not henceforth neglect your schooling M. Chaugh.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Call me Rooke if I doe Tutor.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: And me Rauen, though my name be Trimtram.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Farewell Tutor.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Farewell Vsher.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Thus when the Drum's vnbrast, and Trumpet cease, Soldiers must get pay for to liue in peace. Exeunt

div.stage: Enter the Colonels Sister, meeting the Surgeon.

sp.speaker: Sist.
sp.p:
Oh my most worthy brother, thy hard fate 'twas: Come hither honest Surgeon, and deale faithfully
With a distressed Virgin: what hope is there?

sp.speaker: Surg.
sp.p: Hope, Chillis was scapt miraculously Lady.

sp.speaker: Sist.
sp.p: Whats that sir.

sp.speaker: Surg Cava vena:
sp.p: I care but little for his wound 'ith Orsophag, not thus much trust mee, but when they come to Diaphragma once, the small Intestines, or the Spynall Medull, or i'th Rootes of the Emunctories of the noble parts, then straight I feare a Syncops; the flankes retyring towards the backe, the Vrine bloody, the Excrements purulent, and the Dolour pricking or pungent.

sp.speaker: Sist.
sp.p: Alasse I'me nere the better for this answer.

sp.speaker: Surg.
sp.p: Now I must tell you his principal Dolour lies i'th region of the Liuer, and theres both inflamation and Turmafaction feard, marry I made him a Quadragular plumation, where I vsde Sanguis Draconis; by my faith, with powders incarnatiue, which I temperd with oyle of Hypericon, and other liquors mundificatiue.

sp.speaker: Sist.
sp.p: Pox a your Mundies figatiues, I would they were all fired,

sp.speaker: Surg.
sp.p: But I purpose Lady to make an other experiment at next dressing with a Sarcotricke medicament, made of Iris of Florence. Thus Masticke, Calaphena, Apopanax, Sacrocolla:

sp.speaker: Sist.
sp.p: Sacro-halter, what comfort is i'this to a poore Gentlewoman; pray tell me in plaine tearmes what you thinke of him?

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Marry in plaine tearms I know not what to say to him, the wound I can assure you enclines to Paralisme; and I find his body Cacochimicke: being then in feare of Feuer and inflamation, I nourish him altogeither with Viands refrigeratiue and giue for potion the iuyce of Sauicola, dissolu'd with water Cerefolium: I could doe noe more Lady, if his best Guiguimos were disseuered. Exit.

lg.l: What thankelesse paines does the tongue often take,
To make the whole man most ridiculous:
I come to him for comfort, and he tyres me
Worse then my sorrow, what a pretious good
May be deliuered sweetly in few words:
And what a mount of nothing ha's he cast forth.
Alasse his strength decaies: how cheere you sir,
My honourd Brother?

sp.speaker: Colo.

lg.l: In soule neuer better.
I feele an excellent health there, such a stoutnes,
My inuisible enemy flies mee, seeing me armde
With penitence and forgiuenes, they fall backward,
Whether through admiration, not imagining
There were such armory in a Souldiers soule,
As pardon and repentance: or through power
Of ghostly valour? but I haue bene Lord
Of a more happy conquest in nine howers now,
Then in nine yeares before: Oh kinde Lieftenants
This is the onely war we should prouide for,
Where he that forgiues largest & sighes strongest,
Is a tride Soldier, a true man in deed,
And wins the best field, makes his owne heart bleed.
Read the last part of that Will sir.

sp.p: I also require at the hands of my most beloued Sister, whom I make full Executrix, the disposure of my body in buriall at S. Martins i'th field: and to cause to be distributed to the poore of the same parish, forty Marke, and to the Hospital of maymed Souldiers a hundred: lastly I giue and bequeath to my kinde, deare, and vertuous sister, the full possession of my present estate in riches, whether it be in Lands, Leases, Money, Goods, Plate, Iewels, or what kind soeuer, vpon this condition following, that shee forthwith, tender both her selfe and all these Infeoffments, to that noble Captaine my late Enemy Captaine Ager.

sp.speaker: Colo.
sp.l: Read it againe sir, let her heare it plaine.

lg.l: Pray spare your paines sir, tis too plaine already.
Good sir, how doe you, is your memory perfect?
This Will makes question of you: I bestowde
So much griefe and compassion a your wound,
I neuer look't into your sences Epilepsie:
The sickenes and infirmity of your iudgement
Is to be doubted now, more then your bodies,
Why is your loue no dearer to mee sir,
Then to dispose me so vpon the man,
Whose furie is your bodies present torment?
The Author of your danger: one I hate
Beyond the bounds of malice, doe you not feele
His wrath vpon you? I beseech you sir,
Alter that cruell article.
Cruell sister? (forgiue me naturall loue)
