I must offend thee, speaking to this woman, am I content,
Hauing much kindred, yet to giue thee all,
(Because in thee I'de raise my meanes to goodnesse)
And canst thou prooue so thanklesse to my bounty,
To grudge my soule her peace? is my intent
To leaue her rich, whose onely desire is
To send me poorer into the next world,
Then euer Vsurer went, or politicke Statist?
Is it so burdensome for thee to loue
Where I forgiue? Oh wretched is the man
That buildes the last hopes of his sauing comforts
Vpon a womans charity? hees most miserable,
If it were possible, her obstinate will
Will pull him downe in his midway to heauen,
I'ue wrongd that worthy man past recompence,
And in my anger robd him of faire fame:
And thou the fairest restitution art
My life could yeeld him: if I knewe a fairer,
I'de set thee by and thy vnwilling goodnes,
And neuer make my sacred peace of thee:
But theres the cruelty of a fate debard,
Thou art the last, and all, and thou art hard.
Let your grieu'd heart hold better thoughts of mee,
I will not proue so sir, but since you enforce it,
With such a strength of passion Ile performe,
What by your will you haue inioynd me to,
Though the world neuer shew me ioy agen.
Oh this may be faire cunning for the time,
To put me off, knowing I hold not long,
And when I looke to haue my ioyes accomplish't,
I shall find no such things: that were vilde cosenage,
And not to be repented.
By all the blessednes,
Truth and a good life lookes for, I will doo'te sir,
Comforts reward you for't, when ere you grieue,
I know if you dare sweare I may belieue. Exeunt
No sooner haue I entrance i'this house now,
But all my ioy falls from mee, which was wont
To be the sanctuary of my comforts:
Me thought I lou'd it with a reuerent gladnes,
As holy men doe consecrated Temples
For the Saints sake, which I belieu'd my mother,
But prou'd a false faith since, a fearefull heresie,
O who'de erect th'assurance of his ioyes
Vpon a womans goodnes? whose best vertue,
Is to commit vnseene, and highest secrecie,
To hide but her owne sin, ther's their perfection,
And if shee be so good, which many faile of to,
When these are bad, how wondrous Ill are they,
What comfort I'st to fight, win this dayes fame,
When all my after dayes, are lamps of shame,
Blessings bee firme to me, hee's come tis hee,
A surgeon speedily;
Perhaps you'le say tis but a little wound
Good to preuent a Danger: quick, a surgeon,
I, I, thats all the faust of valiant men,
Theile not be knowne a their hurts till thei'r past helpe,
And then to late they wish for't:
Tis no disparagement to 'confesse a wound,
I'me glad sir tis no worse, a surgeon quickly,
Come, come sir, a woun'd's Honorable,
And neuer shames the wearer,
By the Iustice
I owe to honour, I came of vntouch't,
My teares preuaile then, welcome, welcome sir,
As peace and mercy to one new departed,
Why would you goe though, and deceiue me so,
When my aboundant loue tooke all the course
That might be to preuent it, I did that,
For my affections sake, goodnes forgiue me for't,
That were my owne lifes safety put vppon't,
Ide rather dye then doo't, thinke how you vsd me then,
'And yet would you goe, and hazard your selfe too,
Twas but vnkindly done.
See then how rash you were and short in wisedome,
Why wrong my faith I did, slanderd my constancy,
Belyed my truth, that which few Mothers will,
Or fewer can, I did, out of true feare
And louing care, onely to keep thee heere.
I doubt I am too quick of apprehension, now
And that's a generall fault, when we heere ioyfully,
With the desire of longing fort, I aske it:
Why? were you neuer false,
May death come to me,
Before Repentance then?
I heard it plaine sure,
Not false at all?
By the reward of truth,
I neuer knew that deed
That claimes the name on't.
May then that glorious reward you swore by,
Be neuer failing to you, all the blessings
That you haue giuen me since obedient custome
Taught me to kneel & aske 'um, are not valuable
With this immaculate blessing of your truth:
This is the Palme to victory.
The Crowne for all deserts past, and to come,
Let 'em be numberlesse, they are rewarded,
Already they'r rewarded: blesse this frame
I feele it much too weake to beare the ioy on't.
O pardon me—
I cannot honor you too much, too long,
I kneele not onely to a Mother now,
But to a woman that was neuer false,
Yeare deare, and yeare good too: I thinke a that,
What reuerence doe's she merit tis fit such
Should be distinguisht from the prostrate sexe,
And what distinction properer can be showne,
Then honor done to her that keepes her owne,

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Come sir, Ile haue you rise,

lg.l: To doe a deed then, rises.
That shall for euer raise me: O my glory,
Why this, this is the quarrell that I lookt for,
The tother but a shift to hold time play,
You sacred ministers of preseruation,
For Heauens sake send him life,
And with it mighty health, and such a strength,
May equal but the cause, I wish no foule things,
If life but glow in him he shall know instantly
That I'me resolud to call him to accompt for't.
I bind you by your honor, Madame,
You speake no hindernce too't,
Take heed, you ought not
What an vnhappines haue I in goodnes,
'Tis euer my desire to intend well
But haue no fortunate way in't, for all this
deserue I yet no better of you: but to be greeud agen?
Are you not well with honest gaine of fame,
With safety purchasd, will you needs tempt a ruine,
That auoyds you? Exit Lady.
No y'aue preuaild: things of this nature sprung,
When they vse action must vse little tongue.
Now sir, the newes?
Sir theres a gentlewoman,
Desires some conference with you.
How, with me?
A Gentlewoman? what is she?
Her attendant
Deliuered her to be the Colonels Sister.
Oh for a storme then,
'Lasse poore vertuous Gentlewoman,
I wil indure her violence with much pitty,
She comes to ease her heart good noble soule,
Tis ee'ne a charity to release the burden,
Were, not that remedy ordaind for weomen,
Their hearts would neuer hold three yeares together,
And heere she comes, I neuer markt so much of her,
That face can be the mistris of no anger
But I might very wel indure a month me thinks,
I am the man speake Lady, Ile stand faire.
And Ime enioynd by vow to fall thus low, She kneeles.
And from the dying hand of a repentant
Offer for expiation of wrongs done you,
My selfe, and with my selfe all that was his,
Which vpon that condition was made mine,
Being his soules wish to depart absolute man,
In life a soldier death a Christian.
Oh Heauen has toucht him nobly, how it shames
My vertues slow perfection: rise deere brightnes,
I forget manners too, vp matchlesse sweetnesse,
I must not sir, there is not in my vow
That liberty, I must be receiu'd first,
Or all denyed, if either, I am free,
He must be without soule should deny thee,
And with that reuerence I receiue the guift,
As it was sent me, worthy Colonel,
Has such a conquering way i'th blest things,
Who euer ouercomes, he only wins. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Captaine Albo, a Baud and a Whore.

sp.speaker: Bau.
sp.p: Harke of these hard-hearted Blood-hounds: these Butchers are ee'ne as mercilesse as their Dogs, they knocke downe a Womans fame, ee'ne as it walkes the Streetes by 'um.

sp.speaker: Whor.
sp.p: And the Captaine heere that should defend vs, walkes by like Iohn of the Apple loft.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: What for interiections Prisse? Hem, Euax, Vah: let the Carnisexes scoure their throates: thou knowest there is a curse hangs ouer their bloudy heads, this yeare there shall be more Butchers Pricks burnt then of all trades besides.

sp.speaker: Bau.
sp.p: I doe wonder how thou camest to be a Captaine.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: As thou camest to be a Baud Meg, and Prisse to be a whore, euery one by their deserts.

sp.speaker: Bau.
sp.p: Baud, and Whore? out you vnprofitable raskall, hast not thou beene at the new Play yet, to teach thee better manners: truely they say they are the finest Players, and good speakers of Gentle-women of our quality; Baud and Whore is not mention'd amongst 'um, but the handsomest narrow-mouth'd names they haue for vs, that some of them may serue as well for a Lady, as for one of our occupation.

sp.speaker: Who.
sp.p: Prethee Patronesse, lets goe see a peece of that Play: if we shall haue good words for our mony, tis as much as we can deserue ifaith.

sp.speaker: Bau.
sp.p: I doubt 'tis too late now, but another time Seruant.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Let's goe now sweet face I am acquainted with one of the Pantomimicks, the Bulchins will vse the Irish Captaine with respect, and you two shall bee boxt amongst the better sort.

sp.speaker: Who.
sp.p: Sirra Captaine Albo, I doubt you are but white-liuer'd, looke that you defend vs valiantly, you know your pennance else: Patronesse, you remember how you vs'd him once?

sp.speaker: Bau.
sp.p: I seruant, and I shall neuer forget it, till I vse him so agen: doe you remember Captaine?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Mum Meg, I will not heare on't now.

sp.speaker: Bau.
sp.p: How I and my Amazons stript you as naked as an Indian.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Why Meg?

sp.speaker: Bau.
sp.p: And then how I bound you to the good behauiour, in the open fields.

sp.speaker: Who.
sp.p: And then you strow'd oates vpon his hoppers.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Prethee sweet face.

sp.speaker: Who.
sp.p: And then brought your Ducks to nibble vpon, him you remember?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Oh, the remembrance tortures me agen, no more good sweet face.

sp.speaker: Bau.
sp.p: Well, lead on Sir: but harke a little.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: Didst thou bargaine for the bladders with the Butcher Trim?

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: I sir, I haue 'um heere, I'le practise to swim too sir, and then I may roare with the water at London bridge, he that roares by land and by water both, is the the perfect Roarer.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: Well Ile venter to swim too: if my father in Law giues me a good dowry with his daughter, I shall hold vp my head well enough.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Peace, sir, heere's practise for our roaring, heer's a Centaure, and two Hippocrenes.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: Offer the iustle Trim. Iustle:

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Ha? What meanest thou by that?

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: I meane to confront thee, Cyclops.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: Ile tell thee what a meanes, is this thy Sister?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: How then sir?

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: Why then I say shee is a Bronsterops: and this is a Fucus.

sp.speaker: Who.
sp.p: No indeed sir, we are both Fucusses.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Art thou military? art thou a Soldier?

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: A Soldier, no I scorne to be so poore, I am a Roarer.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: A Roarer?

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: I sir, two Roarers.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: Know then my fresh water friends, that I am a Capten.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: What, and haue but two to serue vnder you?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: I am now retiring the field.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: You may see that by his Bag and Baggage.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: Deliuer vp thy Panagron to me.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: And giue me thy Sindicus.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Deliuer?

sp.speaker: Bau.
sp.p: I pray you Captaine bee contented, the Gentlemen seeme to giue vs very good wordes.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: Good words? I if you could vnderstand 'um, the words cost twenty pound.

sp.speaker: Bau.
sp.p: What is your pleasure Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: I would enucleate my Fructifer.

sp.speaker: Who.
sp.p: What sayes he Patronesse?

sp.speaker: Bau.
sp.p: He would enoculate: I vnderstand the Gentleman very pithily.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Speake, are you Gentile or Plebeyan, can you giue Armes?

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: Armes? I sir, you shall feele our armes presently.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Sault you the Women, Ile pepper him til he stinks agen: I perceiue what Country-man hee is, let mee alone with him.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Dar'st thou charge a Captaine?

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Yes, and discharge vpon him too.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Foh, tis poyson to my Country, the slaue has eaten pippins: Oh shoote no more, turne both thy Broad-sides rather then thy Poope: 'tis foule play: my Country breeds no poyson: I yeelde, the great O Toole shall yeeld on these condicions.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: I haue giuen one of 'um a faire fall Trim.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Then thus farre wee bring home Conquest: follow me Captaine, the Cyclops doth command.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: Follow mee Tweaks, the Centaure doth command.

sp.speaker: Bau.
sp.p: Any thing sweet Gentlemen, wilt please you to lead to the Tauerne, where weele make all friends.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Why now you come to the conclusion.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: Stay, Trim; I haue heard your Tweakes are like your Mer maydes, they haue sweet voyces to entice the passengers: lets haue a Song, and then weele set 'um at liberty.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: In the commendation of Roaring, not else Sir,

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.l: I, in the commendation of Roaring,

lg.head: Sing Baud.
lg.l: THen heere thou shalt resigne
Both Captaine and Commander,
That name was neuer thine,
But Apple-Squire and Pander.
And henceforth will wee grant,
In pillage or in monies,
In cloathing or prouant,
What ere wee get by Conies:
With a hone, a hone, a hone,
No Cheaters nor Decoyes,
Shall haue a share, but alone
The brauest Roaring Boyes.
What are we get by Gulls,
Of Country or of Citty:
Old Flatcaps or young Heyres,
Or Lawyers Clarkes so witty:
By Saylers newly landed,
To put in for fresh waters:
By wandring Gander-mooners:
Or mufled late night-walkers. With a, &c.
What are we get by Strangers,
The Scotch, the Dutch, or Irish:
Or to come nearer home,
By Maisters of the Parish.
It is concluded thus,
By all and euery wench,
To take of all their coynes,
And pay 'um backe in French. With a, &c.

sp.speaker: Bau.
sp.p: We shall neuer be able to deserue these good words at your hands Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Shake golls with the Captaine, hee shall be thy valiant friend.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: Not yet Captaine, wee must make an end of our Roaring first.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Wee'le serue 'um as we did the Tobacco-man: lay a curse vpon 'um, marry wee'le lay it on gently, because they haue vsed vs so kindly, and then wee'le shake gols together.

sp.speaker: Who.
sp.p: As gently as you can, sweet Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: For thee, Oh Pander: maist thou trudge till the damn'd soles of thy boots fleet into durt, but neuer rise into Ayre.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Next, maist thou fleet so long from place to place, till thou beest kickt out of Fleetstreet.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: As thou hast liued by bad flesh, so rotten mutton be thy bane.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: When thou art dead, may twenty whores follow thee, that thou maist goe a Squire to thy graue.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Enough for me sweet faces, let me sleepe in my graue.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: For thee old Sindicus, may I see thee ride in a Caroch with two wheeles, and drawne with one horse.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Ten Beadles running by, in stead of foot-men.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: With euery one a whip, steed of an Irish dart.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Forty Barbers Basons sounding before in steed of Trumpets.

sp.speaker: Bau.
sp.p: This will be comly indeed sweet Gentlemen Roarers.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Thy Russe starch't yellow with rotten Egges.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: And maist thou then be drawne from Holborne, to Hounslow-Heath.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: And then be burnt to Colebrooke for destroying of Maydenhead.

sp.speaker: Bau.
sp.p: I will study to deserue this kindnesse at your hands Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: Now for thee little Fucus, Maist thou first serue out thy time as a Tweake, and then become a Bronstrops as she is.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Maist thou haue a reasonable good Spring, for thou art like to haue many dangerous soule falls.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: Maist thou haue two Ruffes torne in one weeke.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: May Spiders onely weaue thy Cobweb-lawne:

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: Maist thou set vp in Rogue Lane.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Liue till thou stink'st in Garden-Allyes.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: And die sweetly in Tower-Ditch.

sp.speaker: Who.
sp.p: I thanke you for that good sir Roarer.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: Come, shall we goe now Trim, my father in law stayes for me all this while.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Nay, I'le serue 'um as wee did the Tobacco-man: Ile burie 'um altogether, and giue 'um an Epitaph.

sp.speaker: Chaugh.
sp.p: All together Trim, why then the Epitaph will be accessary to the sinne: alas, he has kept the doore all his life time, for pity let 'um lye together in their graues.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: Eene as thou wilt Trim, and I thank you too sir.

lg.l: He that the reason would know, let him harke,
Why these two were buried neere Maribone Parke:
These three were a Pander, a Band, and a Whore,
That suckt many dry to the bones before.
Well you know how they liu'd? heer't may be red,
The low Countries did euer finde 'um bred,
They liu'd by Flushing, by Sluce, and the Greyne,
Sickened in France, and dyed vnder the Line.
Three letters at last commended 'um hither,
But the hangman broke one in putting together.
P. was the first, who cryes out for a Pardon,
O. craues his booke, yet could not read such a hard one,
An X. was the last, which in coniunction
Was broke by Brandon, and heere's the conclusion.
By three trees, three letters; these three, Pander, Band, Whore:
Now stinke below ground, stunke long aboue before.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: So, now we haue done with you, remember Roaring Boyes.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Farewell Centaure.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: Farewell Bronsterops.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Farewell Fucus.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Well Meg: I will learne to Roare, and still maintaine the name of Captaine ouer these Launcepresadoes.

sp.speaker: Bau.
sp.p: If thou do'st not, maist thou bee buried vnder the Roaring curse. Exeunt.

div.head: Actus Quintus, Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter Phisition: Iane as a Bride.

sp.speaker: Phis.
sp.p: Will you be obstinate?

lg.l: Torment me not,
Thou lingring Executioner to death,
Greatest disease to Nature, that striu'st by Art
To make men long a dying, your practise is
Vpon mens bodyes, as men pull Roses,
For their owne relish, but to kill the flower
So you maintaine your liues by others deaths,
What eat you then by carrion?
Fie bitternes,
Ye'ad need to candy ore your tongue a little,
Your wordes will hardly be digested els,
You can giue your selfe a vomit to returne 'um,
If they offend your stomacke,
Heere my vow
You are to be married to day.
A second torment,
Worse then the first, cause vnauoydable,
I would I could as soone annihilate
My Fathers will in that as forbid thy lust.
If you then tender an vnwilling hand,
Meet it with reuenge, marry a Cuckolde.
If thou wilt marry me, Ile make that vow,
And giue my body for satisfaction
To him that should enioy me for his wife.

sp.speaker: Phis.
sp.l: Go to, Ile marre your marriage.

lg.l: Doe, plague me so.
Ile rather beare the brand of all thats past,
In Capitall Characters vpon my Brow,
Then thinke to be thy whore or marry him,
I will produce thy Bastard,
Bring thee to publike pennance,
No matter, I care not,
I shall haue a cleane sheet, Ile weare twenty
Rather then one defil'd with thee.
Pursue it fully then, out of his hate,
I shall pursue (I hope) a loathed fate. Exit Iane
Am I reiected, all my baites nibled off,
And not the fish caught? Ile trouble the whole streame,
And choake it in the mudde, since hookes not take,
Ile throw in nets that shall or kill or breake.
This is the Bridegroomes man, harke sir, a word.
'Tis a busie day sir, nor I need no phisicke,
You see I scoure about my busines.

sp.speaker: Phis.
sp.p: Pray you a word sir, your Maister is to bee married to day.

sp.speaker: Phis.
sp.l: I would speake with your maister sir.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: My Maister sir, is to bee married this morning and cannot be within while soone at night.

lg.l: If you will doe your maister the best seruice,
That ere you did him, if he shall not curse
Your negligence hereafter slacking it:
If he shall blesse mee for the dearest friend
That euer his acquaintance met withall,
Let me speake with him ere he goe to Church.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: A right Phisition, you would haue none goe to the Church, nor Churchyard till you send them thither; well, if death doe not spare you your selues, hee deales hardly with you, for you are better benefactors and send more to him then all diseases besides.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: What Trimtram, Trimtram?

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: I come sir. Harke you, you may heare him, hee's vpon the spur and would faine mount the saddle of Matrimony, but (if I can) Ile perswade him to come to you. Exit Trim

lg.l: Pray you doe sir: Ile teach all peeuish nicenes
To beware the strong aduantage of reuenge.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.l: Who's that would speake with me?

lg.l: None but a friend sir.
I would speake with you.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: Why sir, and I dare speake with any man vnder the vniuerse, can you roare sir?

lg.l: No infaith sir.
I come to tell you mildelie for your good,
If you please to heare me: you are vpon Marriages

sp.speaker: Chau
sp.p: No sir, I an towards it, but not vpon it yet.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.p: Doe you know what you doe?

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: Yes sir, I haue practis'd what to doe before now, I would be asham'd to be married else: I haue seen a Bronstrops in my time, and a Hippocreene, and a Tweke too.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.p: Take fayre heede sir, the wife that you would marry is not fit for you.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Why sir, haue you tried her?

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.p: Not I beleeue it sir, but belieue with all, Shee has beene tryed.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: Why sir, is she a Fructifer? or a Fucus?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: All that I speake sir, is in loue to you, Your Bride, that may be, 'has not that portion that a Bride should haue.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: Why sir? she has a thousand and a better penny.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.p: I doe not speake of rubish, drosse, and ore, But the refined Mettle, Honour sir.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: What she wants in honour shall be made vp in worship sir, money will purchase both.

sp.speaker: Phy,
sp.p: To be plaine with you, she's naught. drawes his sword

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: If thou canst not roare th'art a dead man, my Bride naught?

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.p: Sir, I doe not feare you that way, what I speake, My life shall mainetaine, I say shee's naught.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: Dost thou not feare me?

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.p: Indeed I doe not sir.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: Ile neuer draw vpon the while I liue for that tricke, put vp and speake freely.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.l: Your intended Bride is a whore, thats freely sir,

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: Yes saith, a whor's free enough, and she hath a conscience: is she a whore? Foote I warrant shee has the Poxe then?

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.l: A plaguie whore? a pox on her Ile none of her,

lg.l: Mine accusation shall haue firme euidence.
I will produce an vnauoided witnes,
A bastard of her bearing.

sp.speaker: Chau,
sp.p: A Bastard? 'snailes, ther's great suspition shee's a whore then, Ile wrastle a fall with her father for putting this tricke vpon me as I am a Gentleman.

lg.l: Good sir mistake me not, I doe not speake
To breake the contract of vnited hearts,
I will not pull that curse vpon my head,
To separate the husband and the wife,
But this (in loue) I thought fit to reueale,
(As the due office betwixt man and man)
That you might not be ignorant of your ills,
Consider now of my premonishment,
As your selfe shall please.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: Ile burne all the Rose mary to sweeten the house, for in my conscience tis infected: has she drunke Bastard? if she would pisse me wine Viniger now nine times a day I'de neuer haue her, and I thanke you too.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Come, will you come away sir, they haue all Rosemary and stay for you to lead the way.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: Ile not be married to day Trimtram, has't ere an Almanacke about thee? this is the nintenth of August, looke what day of the month 'tis. Lookes in an Almanacke.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.l: What's the word? what sayes Bretnor?

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: The word is sir, theres a hole in her coate.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: I thought so, the Physition agrees with him, Ile not marry to day.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: I pray you sir, there will be charges for new Rosemary else, this will be wither'd by to morrow.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: Make a Bon fire ont to sweeten Rosemary Lane prethee Trim. entreat my father in law that might haue beene, to come and speake with me.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: The Bride cries already and lookes to ther way, and you be so backward too, we shall haue a fine arseward wedding on't. Exit Trim.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.l: Youle stand to your words, sir?

sp.speaker: Phis.
sp.p: Ile not flye the house sir, when you haue need call me to euidence. Exit Phisition.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: If youle proue she has borne a Bastard, Ile stand too't shee's a whore.

sp.speaker: Russ.
sp.p: Why how now sonne what causeth these delayes? All stay for your leading.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.l: Came I from the mount to be confronted?

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: Why then Ile tell thee plainely thy daughter in a Bronstrops.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Sir if she be so she is a Hippocrene.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.l: Nay worse she is a fructifer.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Nay then she is a Fucus, a Minotaure, and a Tweke.

sp.speaker: Russ.
sp.l: Pray you speake to my vnderstanding sir,

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: If thou wilt haue it in plaine termes: She is a Callicut, and a Panagron.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Nay then she is a Duplar and a Sindicus.

sp.speaker: Russ.
sp.l: Good sir, speake English to me.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: All this is Cornish to thee, I say thy Daughter has drunke Bastard in her time.

sp.speaker: Russ.
sp.l: Bastard you doe not meane to make her a whore?

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: Yes but I doe, if shee make a foole of me, Ile nere make her my wife, till she haue her maidenhead agen?

sp.speaker: Russ.
sp.l: A whore? I doe defie this Callumnie.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.l: Dost thou? I defie thee then.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Doe you sir, then I defie thee too, fight with vs both at once in this quarrell if thou darest.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.l: I could haue had a whore at Plimouth.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Or as you came, at Euill.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.l: Or at Hoc-kye hole in Somersetshire.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Or at the hanging stones in Wiltshire.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: Or at Maidenhead in Barkshire: and did I come in by Maidenhead to goe out by Staines? Oh that man woman or childe, would wrastle with me for a pound of patience.

lg.l: Some thiefe has put in poyson at your eares.
To steale the good name of my child from me:
Or if it be a mallice of your owne,
Be sure I will enforce a proofe from you.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: Hees a goose and a woodcocke that sayes I will not proue any word that I speake.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: I either goose or Woodcocke he shall sir with any man.

lg.l: Sir, with much sorrow for your sorrowes sake,
I must deliuer this most certaine truth,
Your daughter is an honor stayned Bride,
Indeed she is the mother to a child,
Before the lawfull wife vnto a husband.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: Law, thats worse then I told thee, I said shee had borne a Bastard, and hee sayes she was the mother ont too.

lg.l: I'me yet an infidell against all this,
And will beleeue the Sun is made of Brasse,
The Starres of amber.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.l: And the moone of a holland cheese.

sp.speaker: Russ.
sp.l: Rather then this impossibility, oh, heere she comes,

lg.l: Nay come daughter, stand at the barre of shame,
Either now quit thy selfe, or kill me euer:
Your marriage day is spoyld if all bee true.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.l: A happy misery, whose my accuser?

sp.speaker: Phis.
sp.l: I am that knowes it true I speake,

lg.l: And I agen too,
theres foure thats enough I hope.
How can you witnes sir that nothing know,
But what you haue receiu'd from his report.
Must we not beleeue our Phisitians? pray you thinke
I know as much as euery foole do's.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Let me be Trimtram: I pray you too sir.

lg.l: Sir if this bad man haue layd a blemish
On my white name: he is a most false one,
Defaming me for the iust denyall
Of his soule lust, nay now you shall be known sir.
Sir Ime his sister and do better know him,
Then all of you giue not too much beliefe
To his wilde wordes, hee's oftentimes mad sir.
Are you not mad to doe this Office,
Fie vppon your mallice.
Ile presently produce both nurse and Child,
Whose very eyes shall call her mother, before it speakes.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha, by my troth Ide spend a shilling on that condition to heare that, I thinke in my conscience I shal take the Phisitian in a lye if the Childe call her mother before it can speake, Ile neuer wrastle while I liue agen.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: It must be a shee child if it doe sir, and those speake the soonest of any liuing Creatures they say.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: Baw waw, a dog will barke a Month sooner, hee's a very puppy else.

lg.l: Come tell truth twixt our selues, heers none but friends
One spot a fathers loue will soone wipe off?
The truth and they trie my loue abundant,
Ile couer it with all the care I haue.
And yet (perhaps) make vp a marriage day.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.l: Then its true sir, I haue Child.

lg.l: Hast thou?
Well wipe thine eyes, Ime a Grandfather then,
If all bastards were banisht, the Citty would be thinne,
In the thickest terme time, well now let me alone
Ile try my wits for thee, Richard, Francis, Andrew,
None of my knaues within?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Heere's one of'um, sir, the Guests come in apace.

sp.speaker: Russ.
sp.p: Doe they dick? let 'um haue wine and sugar, weele befor 'um presently, but harke Dick.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: I long to heare this childe speake ifaith, Trim, I would this foolish Phisition would come once.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: If it calls her mother, I hope it shall neuer call you father.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: No, and it do Ile whip it ifaith, and giue thee leaue to whip me.

sp.speaker: Russ.
sp.l: Run on thy best legges Dicke.

sp.speaker: Seru.
sp.l: Ile be heere in a twinkling sir. Exit Ser.

div.stage: Enter Phisitian, Nurse, with the childe.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.p: Now Gentlemen, beleeue your eyes, if not my tongue Doe not you call this your childe?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Phew, thats not the point you promis'd vs the child should call her Mother, if it do's this month, Ile nere go to the roaring schoole agen.

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.l: Dis Gentlemans, so he to me readen. Poynts to the Phisitian.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Snailes shees the Phisitians Bronstrops, Trim.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: His Fucus, his very Tweke, ifaith.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: A glister in his teeth, let him take her with a purgation to him.

lg.l: 'Tis as your sister said: you are starke mad, sir,
This much confirmes it, you haue defamed
Mine honest daughter: Ile haue you punisht fort,
Besides the ciuill pennance of your sinne,
And keeping of your bastard.
This is fine,
All your wit and wealth must not thus carry it.

sp.speaker: Russ.
sp.l: Sir Chaugh a word with you.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: Ile not haue her ifaith, sir, if Trimtram will haue her and he will let him.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Who I, sir? I scorne it, if you'l haue her, Ile haue her too, Ile doe as you doe, and no otherwise.

lg.l: I doe not meant to either, this onely, sir,
That whatsoere y'aue seene, you would be silent,
Hinder not my child of another husband,
Though you forsake her.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.l: Ile not speake a word, ifaith,

lg.l: By these basket hilts, as I am a youth,
A gentleman a Roarer.

sp.speaker: Russ.
sp.l: Charme your man I beseech you too.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: I warrant you sir hee shall doe nothing but what I doe before him.

lg.l: I shall most dearly thanke you, Oh are you come,
Welcome sonne in law: this was beyond your hope,
We old men haue pretty conceits sometimes,
Your Wedding daye's prepard, and this is it,
How thinke you of it?
As of the ioyfulst
That euer welcomd me, you shew your selfe now
A patterne to all kind fathers: my sweetest Iane,
Your captiuity I mean't but as sauce,
Vnto your Wedding dinner, now, I'me sure
'Tis far more welcome in this short restraint
Then had it freely come:

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: I haue not the heart to see this Gentleman guld so, I will reueale, I make it mine owne case tis a foule case.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Remember you haue sworne by your hilts.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.p: Ile break my hilts rather then conceale, I haue a trick Doe thou follow mee, I will reueale it, and yet not speake it neither.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: 'Tis my duty to follow you sir.

sp.speaker: Chaugh
sp.l: sings .Take heed in time oh man vnto thy head,

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Sings .All is not gold that glistereth in bed.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.l: Looke too't I say, thy Bride's a Bronsterops,

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: And knowes the thing that men weare in their slops,

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.l: A Hipocrene, a Tweke, for and a fucus,

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Let not fond loue with foretops so rebuke vs.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.l: Behold a baby of this maids begetting,

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: A deed of darknes after the sun-setting.

sp.speaker: Chau:
sp.l: I sweare and sing thy Bride has taken Phisike,

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: This was the Doctor curd her of that Ptisicke.

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.l: If you'le beleeue me I will say no more,

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Thy Brides a Tweke as we doe say that roare.

lg.l: Beare witnes Gentlemen I haue not spoke a word,
My hilts are hole still.
This is a sweet Epithalamium,
Vnto the Marriage bed, a musicall
Harmonius Io: sir, yaue wrongd me,
And basely wrong'd me, was this your cunning fetch,
To Fetch me out of prison, for euer
To marry me vnto a Strumpet?
None of those words good sir,
Tis but a fault, and tis a sweet one too,
Come sir, your meanes is short, lengthen your fortunes,
With a faire proffer: Ile put a thousand pieces
Into the scale to helpe her to weigh it vp,
Aboue the first dowrie.
Ha? you say, well
Shame may be bought out at a deere rate,
A thousand pieces added to her dowry.
Theres fiue hundred of 'um to make the Bargaine,
I haue worthy guests comming and would not delude 'um,
Say: speake like a Sonne to me.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.p: Your blessing sir, we are both yours, witnes Gentlemen these must be made vp a thousand pieces, added to a first thousand for her dowry, to father that childe,

sp.speaker: Chau.
sp.l: For tother thousand Ile doo't my selfe yet.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Or I, if my Maister will.

lg.l: The Bargaine's made, sir, I haue the tender
And possession both; and will keepe my purchase,

sp.speaker: Chaw.
sp.p: Take her eene to you with all her moueables, ile weare my batchellors buttons still.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: So will I ifaith; they are the best flowers in any mans garden, next to hartsease.

lg.l: This is as welcome as the other sir,
And both as the best blisse that ere on earth,
I shall enioy, sir, this is mine owne childe,
You could not haue found out a sitter Father
Nor is it basely bred as you imagine
For we were wedded by the hand of heauen
Ere this worke was begun.

sp.speaker: Chaw.
sp.l: At Pancridge, ile lay my life on't,

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: I'le lay my life on't too, twas there,

lg.l: And that I must haue reuea'ld to you, sir,
Ete I had gone to Church with this faire groome,
But thanke this gentleman, he preuented me,
I am much bound vnto your mallice sir.
Now get you together for a couple of cunning ones,
But sonne, a word, the latter thousand peeces
Is now more then bargaine.
No by my faith sir
Here's witnesse inough ont, must serue to pay my fees
Imprisonment is costly

sp.speaker: Chaw.
sp.p: By my troth the old man ha's gul'd himselfe, finely, well sir, Ile bid my selfe a guest, though not a groome, Ile dine and dance, and roare at the wedding for all this.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: So will I sir, if my Maister does,

lg.l: Well sir, you are welcome, but now, no more wordes on't,
Till we be set at dinner for there will mirth
Be the most vsefull for digestion,
See, my best guests are comming.

div.stage: Enter Captaine Ager, Surgeon, Lady Ager Colonells Sister, two friends.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Recouerd saist thou.

sp.speaker: Surg.
sp.p: May I bee excluded quite out of Surgeons hall else, marry I must tell you the wound was faine to be twice Coroded, 'twas a plaine Gastrolophe, and a deep one, but I closed the lips on't with Bandages and Sutteures, which is a kind coniunction of the parts seperated against the course of nature.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Well sir, he is well

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: I feard him I assure you Captaine before the Surture in the belly, it grew almost to a convulsion, and there was like to be a bloody issue from the hollow vessells of the kidnyes.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: There's that, to thanke thy news and thy Art together.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: And if your worship at any time stand in need of incission, if it be your fortune to light into my hands, ile giue you the best.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Vncle, the noble Colonells recouerd,

lg.l: Recouered.
Then honor is not dead in all parts Cusse.

div.stage: Enter Colonell with his too friends.

sp.p: Behold him yonder sir.

lg.l: My much vnworthinesse is now found out,
Tha'st not a face to fit it.
O Lieftenant the wrong I haue done his fame,
Puts me to silence, shame so confounds me,
That I dare not see him.
I neuer knew how poore my deserts were,
Till he appeard'; no way to giue requitall,
Here shame me lastingly; doo't with his owne,
Returne this to him, tell him I haue Riches
In that abundance in his sisters loue,
These come but to oppresse me, and confound
All my deseruings euerlastingly:
I neuer shall requite my wealth in her say,
How soone from vertue and an honord spirit,
May man receiue what he may neuer merit.
This comes most happily, to expresse me better,
For since this will was made there fell to me
The manner of Fitz-dale, giue h'um that too,
Hee's like to haue chardge theres faire hope
Of my sisters fruitfullnesse, for me
I neuer meane to change my mistris,
And warre is able to maintaine her seruant,
Read there, a faire increase sir, by my faith,
He hath sent it backe sir, with new additions.
How miserable he makes me, this inforces me
To breake through all the passadges of shame
And headlong fall,
You haue a goodnesse
Has put me past my answers, you may speake,
what you please now; I must be silent euer,
This day has showen me ioyes vnualeu'd treasure,
I would not change this brotherhood with a monarch,
Into which blest aliance sacred heauen
Ha's plac't my kinsman, and giuen him his ends
Faire be that Quarrell makes such happy friends.

div.head: Notes, typically marginal, from the original text
Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-digit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a keyword in context.
